books.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:1
verses.text: Exposition of the Christian Faith, Book V: Prologue.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:2
verses.text: Who is a faithful and wise servant? His reward is pointed out in the case of Peter, as also in the case of Paul.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:3
verses.text: Ambrose, being anxious to follow Paul's guidance, wished this book to be added to the others, for it could not be included in the preceding one.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:4
verses.text: The subject for discussion is then stated, and the reason for such a discussion given.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:5
verses.text: He must needs be pardoned, for usury is to be demanded from every servant for the money which has been entrusted to him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:6
verses.text: Their faithfulness is the usury desired in his own case.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:7
verses.text: He will be happy if he may hope for a reward; but he does not look so much for the recompense of the saints, as for exemption from punishment.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:8
verses.text: He urges all to seek to merit this.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:9
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:10
verses.text: "Who, then, is a faithful and wise servant, whom his lord hath made ruler over his household, to give them meat in due season? Blessed is that servant, whom his lord when he cometh shall find so doing".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:11
verses.text: Not worthless is this servant: some great one ought he to be.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:12
verses.text: Let us think who he may be.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:13
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:14
verses.text: It is Peter, chosen by the Lord Himself to feed His flock, who merits thrice to hear the words: "Feed My little lambs; feed My lambs; feed My sheep".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:15
verses.text: And so, by feeding well the flock of Christ with the food of faith, he effaced the sin of his former fall.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:16
verses.text: For this reason is he thrice admonished to feed the flock; thrice is he asked whether he loves the Lord, in order that he may thrice confess Him, Whom he had thrice denied before His Crucifixion.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:17
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:18
verses.text: Blessed also is that servant who can say: "I have fed you with milk and not with meat; for hitherto ye were not able to bear it".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:19
verses.text: For he knew how to feed them.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:20
verses.text: Who of us can do this? Who of us can truly say: "To the weak became I as weak, that I might gain the weak"?  4.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:21
verses.text: Yet he, being so great a man, and chosen by Christ for the care of His flock, so as to strengthen the weak and to heal the sick,—he, I say, rejects forthwith after one admonition a heretic from the fold entrusted to him, for fear that the taint of one erring sheep might infect the whole flock with a spreading sore.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:22
verses.text: He further bids that foolish questions and contentions be avoided.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:23
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:24
verses.text: How, then, shall we act, being but ignorant dwellers set amongst these fresh tares in the old-standing harvest field? If  we are silent, we shall seem to be giving way; and if we contend against them, there is the fear that we too shall be held to be carnal.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:25
verses.text: For it is written of matters of this sort, which beget strife: "The servant of the Lord must not strive, but be gentle unto all, apt to teach, patient, with moderation instructing those that oppose themselves".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:26
verses.text: And in another place: "If any man is contentious, we have no such custom, neither the Church of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:27
verses.text: For this reason it was our intention to write somewhat, in order that our writings might without any din answer the impiety of heretics on our behalf.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:28
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:29
verses.text: And so we prepare to commence this our Fifth Book, O Emperor Augustus.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:30
verses.text: For it was but right that the Fourth Book should end with our discussion on the Vine, lest otherwise we should seem to have overloaded that book with a tumultuous mass of subjects, rather than to have filled it with the fruit of the spiritual vineyard.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:31
verses.text: On the other hand, it was not seemly that the gathering of the vintage of the faith should be left unfinished, whilst there was still all abundance of such great matters for discussion.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:32
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:33
verses.text: In the Fifth Book, therefore, we speak of the indivisible Godhead of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost (omitting, however, a full discussion on the Holy Ghost), being urged by the teaching of the Gospel to let out on interest to human minds the five talents of the faith entrusted to these five books being as it were the principal; lest perhaps when the Lord comes, and finds His money hidden in the earth, He may say to me: "Thou wicked and slothful servant, thou knewest that I reap where I do not sow; and gather where I have not strawed; thou oughtest therefore to have put My money to the exchangers, that at My coming I might have received Mine Own," or as it stands in another book: "And I," it says, "at My coming might have received it with usury".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:34
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:35
verses.text: I pray those to pardon me, whom the boldness of such a lengthy address displeases.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:36
verses.text: The thought of my office compels me to entrust to others what I have received.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:37
verses.text: "We are stewards of the heavenly mysteries".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:38
verses.text: We are ministers, but not all alike.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:39
verses.text: "But," it says, "even as the Lord gave to every man, I have planted; Apollos watered; but God gave the increase".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:40
verses.text: Let each one then strive that be may be able to receive a reward according to his labour.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:41
verses.text: "For we are labourers together with God," as the Apostle said; "we are God's husbandry, God's building".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:42
verses.text: Blessed therefore is he who sees such usury on his principal; blessed too is he who beholds the fruit of his work; blessed again is he "who builds upon the foundation of faith, gold, silver, precious stones".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:43
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:44
verses.text: Ye who hear or read these words are all things to us.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:45
verses.text: Ye are the usury of the money-lender,—the usury on speech, not on money; ye are the return given to the husbandman; ye are the gold, the silver, the precious stones of the builder.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:46
verses.text: In your merits lie the chief results of the labours of the priest; in your souls shines forth the fruit of a bishop's work; in your progress glitters the gold of the Lord; the silver is increased if ye hold fast the divine words.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:47
verses.text: "The words of the Lord are pure words, as silver tried in the fire; proved on the earth, purified seven times".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:48
verses.text: Ye therefore will make the lender rich, the husbandman to abound in produce; ye will prove the master-builder to be skilful.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:49
verses.text: I do not speak boastfully; for I do not desire so much my own advantage as yours.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:50
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:51
verses.text: Oh that I might safely say of you at that time: "Lord, Thou gavest me five talents, behold I have gained five other talents;" and that I might show the precious talents of your virtues! "For we have a treasure in earthen vessels".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:52
verses.text: These are the talents which the Lord bids us spiritually to trade with, or the two coins of the New and the Old Testament, which that Samaritan in the Gospel left for the man robbed by the thieves, for the purpose of getting his wounds healed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:53
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:54
verses.text: Neither do I, my brethren, with greedy desires, long for this, so that I may be set over many things; the recompense I get from the fact of your advance is enough for me.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:55
verses.text: Oh that I may not be found unworthy of that which I have received! Let those things which are too great for me be assigned to better men.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:56
verses.text: I demand them not! Yet mayest Thou say, O Lord: "I will give unto this last, even as unto thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:57
verses.text: Let the man that deserves it receive authority over ten cities.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:58
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:59
verses.text: Let him be such an one as was Moses, who wrote the Ten Words of the Law.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:60
verses.text: Let him be as Joshua, the son of Nun, who subdued five kings, and brought the Gibeonites into subjection, that he might be the figure of a Man of his own name Who was  to come, by Whose power all fleshly lust should be overcome, and the Gentiles should be converted, so that they might follow the faith of Jesus Christ rather than their former pursuits and desires.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:61
verses.text: Let him be as David, whom the young maidens came to meet with songs, saying: "Saul hath triumphed over thousands, David over ten thousands".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:62
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:63
verses.text: It is enough for me, if I am not thrust out into the outer darkness, as he was, who hid the talent entrusted to him in the earth so to speak, of his own flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:64
verses.text: This the ruler of the synagogue did, and the other rulers of the Jews; for they employed, the words of the Lord, which had been entrusted to them, on the ground as it were of their bodies; and, delighting in the pleasures of the flesh, sunk the heavenly trust as though into the pit of an overweening heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:65
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:66
verses.text: Let us then not keep the Lord's money buried and hidden in the flesh; nor let us hide our one talent in a napkin; but like good money-changers let us ever weigh it out with labour of mind and body, with an even and ready will, that the word may be near, even in thy mouth and in thy heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:67
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:68
verses.text: This is the word of the Lord, this is the precious talent, whereby thou art redeemed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:69
verses.text: This money must often be seen on the tables of souls, in order that by constant trading the sound of the good coins may be able to go forth into every land, by the means of which eternal life is purchased.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:70
verses.text: "This is eternal life," which Thou, Almighty Father, givest freely, that we may know "Thee the only true God, and Jesus Christ Whom Thou hast sent".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:71
verses.text: Chapter I.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:72
verses.text: How impious the Arians are, in attacking that on which human happiness depends.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:73
verses.text: John ever unites the Son with the Father, especially where he says: "That they may know Thee, the only true God, etc".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:74
verses.text: In that place, then, we must understand the words "true God" also of the Son; for it cannot be denied that He is God, and it cannot be said He is a false god, and least of all that He is God by appellation only.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:75
verses.text: This last point being proved from the Apostle's words, we rightly confess that Christ is true God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:76
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:77
verses.text: Wherefore let the Arians observe, how impious they are in calling in question our hope and the object of our desires.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:78
verses.text: And since they are wont to cry out on this point above all others, saying that Christ is distinct from the only and true God, let us confute their impious ideas so far as lies in our power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:79
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:80
verses.text: For on this point they ought rather to understand, that this is the benefit, this the reward of perfect virtue, namely, this divine and incomparable gift, that we may know Christ together with the Father, and not separate the Son from the Father; as also the Scriptures do not separate them.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:81
verses.text: For the following tells rather for the unity than for the diversity of the Divine Majesty, namely, that the knowledge of the Father and of the Son gives us the same recompense, and one and the same honour; which reward no man will have but he that has known both the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:82
verses.text: For as the knowledge of the Father procures eternal life, so also does the knowledge of the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:83
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:84
verses.text: Therefore as the Evangelist forthwith at the outset joined the Word with God the Father in his devout confession of faith, saying: "And the Word was with God;" and here too, in writing the words of the Lord: "That they may know Thee, the only true God, and Jesus Christ Whom Thou hast sent," he has undoubtedly, by thus connecting Them, bound together the Father and the Son, so that no one may separate Christ as true God from the majesty of the Father, for union does not dissever.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:85
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:86
verses.text: Therefore in saying, "That they may know Thee, the only true God, and Jesus Christ Whom Thou hast sent," he put an end to the Sabellians, and has also put the Jews out of court,—those at any rate who heard him speak; so that the former might not suppose the Same to be the Father as the Son, which they might have done if he had not added also Christ, and that the latter might not sever the Son from the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:87
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:88
verses.text: But, I ask, why do they not think we ought to gather and understand this from what has been already said; that as he has declared the Father to be only, true God, so we may understand Jesus Christ also to be only, true God? For it could not be expressed in any other way, for fear he might seem to be speaking of two Gods.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:89
verses.text: For neither do we speak of two Gods; and yet we confess the Son to be of the same Godhead with the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:90
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:91
verses.text: May we ask, therefore, on what grounds they think a distinction is made in the Godhead, and whether they deny Christ to be God? But they cannot deny it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:92
verses.text: Do they deny Him to be true God? But if they  deny Him to be true God, let them say whether they declare Him to be a false God, or God by appellation only.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:93
verses.text: For according to the Scriptures the word "God" is used either of the true God, or by appellation only, or of a false god.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:94
verses.text: True God as the Father; God by appellation as the saints; a false god like the demons and idols.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:95
verses.text: Let them say then how they will acknowledge and describe the Son of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:96
verses.text: Do they suppose the name of God to have been falsely assumed; or was there in truth merely an indwelling of God within Him, as it were by appellation only?  22.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:97
verses.text: I do not think they can say the name was falsely assumed, and so involve themselves in the open wickedness of blasphemy; lest they should betray themselves on the one hand to the demons and idols, and on the other to Christ, by insinuating that the name of God was falsely given to Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:98
verses.text: But if they think He is called God because He had an indwelling of the Godhead within Him,—as many holy men were (for the Scripture calls them Gods to whom the word of God came),—they do not place Him before other men, but think He is to be compared with them; so that they consider Him to be the same as He has granted other men to be, even as He says to Moses: "I have made thee a god unto Pharaoh".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:99
verses.text: Wherefore it is also said in the Psalms: "I have said, ye are gods".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:100
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:101
verses.text: This idea of these blasphemers Paul puts aside; for he said: "For though there be that are called gods, whether in heaven or in earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:102
verses.text: He said not: "There be gods," but "There be that are called gods".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:103
verses.text: But "Christ," as it is written, "is the same yesterday and to-day".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:104
verses.text: "He is," it says; that is, not only in name but also in truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:105
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:106
verses.text: And well is it written: "He is the same yesterday and to-day," so that the impiety of Arius might find no room to pile up its profanity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:107
verses.text: For he, in reading in the second psalm of the Father saying to the Son, "Thou art My Son, this day have I begotten Thee," noted the word "to-day," not "yesterday," referring this which was spoken of the assumption of our flesh to the eternity of the divine generation; of which Paul also says in the Acts of the Apostles: "And we declare unto you the promise which was made to our fathers: for God has fulfilled the same to our children, in that He hath raised up the Lord Jesus Christ again, as it is written in the second psalm: Thou art My Son, this day have I begotten Thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:108
verses.text: Thus the Apostle, filled with the Holy Ghost, in order that he might destroy that fierce madness of his, said: "The same, yesterday, to-day, and for ever".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:109
verses.text: "Yesterday" on account of His eternity; "to-day" on account of His taking to Himself a human body.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:110
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:111
verses.text: Christ therefore is, and always is; for He, Who is, always is.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:112
verses.text: And Christ always is, of Whom Moses says: "He that is hath sent me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:113
verses.text: Gabriel indeed was, Raphael was, the angels were; but they who sometime have not been are by no means with equal reason said always to be.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:114
verses.text: But Christ, as we read, "was not it is, and, it is not, but, it is was in Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:115
verses.text: Wherefore it is the property of God alone to be, Who ever is.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:116
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:117
verses.text: Therefore if they dare not say He is God by appellation, and it is a mark of deep impiety to say He is a false god, it remains that He is true God, not unlike to the true Father, but equal to Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 1:118
verses.text: And as He sanctifies and justifies whom He will, not by assuming that power from without Himself, but having within Himself the power of sanctification, how is He not true God? For the Apostle called Him indeed true God, Who according to His nature was God, as it is written: "Howbeit then, when ye knew not God, ye did service unto them, who by nature were not gods;" that is, who could not be true gods, for this title by no means belonged to them by nature.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:1
verses.text: Chapter II.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:2
verses.text: Since it has been proved that the Son is true God, and in that is not inferior to the Father, it is shown that by the word solus (alone) when used of the Father in the Scriptures, the Son is not excluded; nay, that this expression befits Him above all, and Him alone.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:3
verses.text: The Trinity is alone, not amongst all, but above all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:4
verses.text: The Son alone does what the Father does, and alone has immortality.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:5
verses.text: But we must not for this reason separate Him from the Father in our controversies.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:6
verses.text: We may, however, understand that passage of the Incarnation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:7
verses.text: Lastly the Father is shut out from a share in the redemption of men by those who would have the Son to be separated from Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:8
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:9
verses.text: We have fully demonstrated by passages of Scripture, in the earlier books, that Christ is true, yea, very true God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:10
verses.text: Therefore if Christ, as it has been taught, is true God, let us enquire why they desire to separate the Son from the Father, when they read that the Father is the only true God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:11
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:12
verses.text: If they say that the Father alone is true God, they cannot deny that God the Son alone is the Truth; for Christ is the Truth.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:13
verses.text: Is the Truth then something inferior to Him that is true, seeing that according to the use of terms a man is called true from the word "truth," as also wise from wisdom, just from justice? We do not deem it so between the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:14
verses.text: For there is nothing wanting to the Father, because the Father is full of truth; and the Son, because He is the Truth, is equal to Him that is true.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:15
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:16
verses.text: But that they may know, when they see the word "alone," that the Son is in no wise to be separated from the Father, let them remember it was said by God in the Prophets: "I stretched forth the heavens alone".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:17
verses.text: The Father certainly did not stretch them forth without the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:18
verses.text: For the Son Himself, Who is the Wisdom of God, says: "When He prepared the heavens I was present with Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:19
verses.text: And Paul declares that it was said of the Son: "Thou, Lord, in the beginning hast laid the foundation of the earth, and the heavens are the work of Thy hands".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:20
verses.text: Whether therefore the Son made the heavens, as also the Apostle would have it understood, whilst He Himself certainly did not alone spread out the heavens without the Father; or as it stands in the Book of Proverbs: "The Lord in wisdom hath founded the earth, in understanding hath He prepared the heavens;" it is proved that neither the Father made the heavens alone without the Son, nor yet the Son without the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:21
verses.text: And yet He who spread out the heavens is said to be alone.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:22
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:23
verses.text: To show indeed how plainly we must understand the expression "alone" of the Son (although we may never believe that He did anything without the knowledge of the Father), we have here also another passage, where it is written: "Which alone spreadeth out the heavens, and walketh as it were on a pavement over the sea".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:24
verses.text: For the Gospel of the Lord has taught us that it was not the Father but the Son that walked upon the sea, when Peter asked Him, saying, "Lord, bid me come unto Thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:25
verses.text: But even prophecy itself gives proof of this.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:26
verses.text: For holy Job prophesied of the coming of the Lord; of Whom he said in truth that He would vanquish the great Leviathan, and it was done.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:27
verses.text: For that dread Leviathan that is, the devil, He smote, and struck down, and laid low in the last times by the adorable Passion of His own Body.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:28
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:29
verses.text: The Son therefore is only and true God for this also is assigned to the Son as His sole right.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:30
verses.text: For of no created being can it be accurately said that he is alone.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:31
verses.text: How can he to whom fellowship in creation belongs be separated from the rest, as though he were alone? Thus man is seen to be a rational being amongst all earthly creatures, yet he is not the only rational being; for we know that the heavenly works of God also are rational, we confess that angels and archangels are rational beings.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:32
verses.text: If then the angels are rational, man cannot be said to be the only rational being.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:33
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:34
verses.text: But they say that the sun can be said to be alone, because there is no second sun.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:35
verses.text: But the sun himself has many things in common with the stars, for he travels across the heavens, he is of that ethereal and heavenly substance, he is a creature, and is reckoned amongst all the works of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:36
verses.text: He serves God in union with all, blesses Him with all, praises Him with all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:37
verses.text: Therefore he cannot accurately be said to be alone, for he is not set apart from the rest.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:38
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:39
verses.text: Wherefore since no created being can be compared with the Godhead of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost, Which is alone, not amongst all, but over all (our declaration concerning the Spirit being meanwhile held back); as the Father is said to be the only true God, because He has nothing in common with others; so also is the Son alone the Image of the true God, He alone is the Hand of the Father, He alone is the Virtue and Wisdom of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:40
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:41
verses.text: Thus the Son alone does what the Father does; for it is written: "Whatsoever things I do, He doth".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:42
verses.text: And since the work of the Father and of the Son is one, it is well said of the Father and the Son, that God worked alone; wherefore also when we speak of the Creator, we own both the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:43
verses.text: For assuredly when Paul said, "Who served the creature more than the Creator," he neither denied the Father to be the Creator, from Whom are all these things, nor yet the Son, through Whom are all things.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:44
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:45
verses.text: And it does not seem out of agreement with this that it is written: "Who alone hath immortality".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:46
verses.text: For how could He not have immortality Who has life in Himself? He has it in His nature; He has it in His essential Being; and He has it not as a temporal  grace, but owing to His eternal Godhead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:47
verses.text: He has it not by way of a gift as a servant, but by peculiar right of His Generation, as the co-eternal Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:48
verses.text: He has it, too, as has the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:49
verses.text: "For as the Father hath life in Himself, so also hath He given to the Son to have life in Himself".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:50
verses.text: As He has it, it says, so He has given it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:51
verses.text: Thou hast learnt already how He gave it, that thou mayest not think it to be a free gift of grace, when it is a secret of His generation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:52
verses.text: Since, then, there is no divergence of life between the Father and the Son, how can it be supposed that the Father alone has immortality, whilst the Son has it not?  36.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:53
verses.text: Wherefore let them understand that in this passage the Son is not to be separated from the Father, Who is the only true God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:54
verses.text: For they cannot prove that the Son is not the only and true God, especially as here also it may be gathered, as I have said, that Christ too is true and only God; or the passage may at least be understood partly in reference to the Godhead of the Father and the Son, and partly to the Incarnation of Christ: for knowledge is not perfect unless it confesses Jesus Christ from eternity to be only-begotten God, true Son of God, and, according to the flesh, begotten of a Virgin.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:55
verses.text: Which also this very Evangelist has taught us elsewhere, saying: "Every spirit that confesseth that Jesus Christ is come in the flesh, is of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:56
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:57
verses.text: Lastly, the whole of our passage teaches us that it is not improper in this verse to understand a reference to the sacrament of the Incarnation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:58
verses.text: For thus it is written: "Father, the hour is come, glorify Thy Son".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:59
verses.text: When, therefore, He states that the hour is come, and prays to be glorified, how can one suppose Him to have spoken but only in accordance with the assumption of our flesh? For the Godhead has no fixed moments of time, nor does eternal light stand in need of glorification.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:60
verses.text: Therefore in the only true God, Who is the Father, we also understand the only true Son of God to be in accordance with the unity of the Godhead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:61
verses.text: And in the name of Jesus Christ, which He received when born of the Virgin, we acknowledge the sacrament of the Incarnation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:62
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:63
verses.text: But if they wish to separate the Son, when they read that the Father is the only true God, I suppose that when they read of the Incarnation of the Son: "This is the stone which was set at naught of you builders, which is become the head of the corner;" and further: "There is none other name under heaven given among men, whereby we must be saved;" then they imagine the Father is to be cut off from the benefit of imparting salvation to us.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 2:64
verses.text: But there is neither salvation without the Father, nor eternal life without the Son.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:1
verses.text: Chapter III.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:2
verses.text: To the objection of the Arians, that two Gods are introduced by a unity of substance, the answer is that a plurality of Gods is more likely to be inferred from diversity of substance.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:3
verses.text: Further, their charge recoils upon themselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:4
verses.text: Manifold diversity is the reason why two men cannot be said to be one man, though all men are called individually man, where a unity of nature is referred to.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:5
verses.text: There is one nature alone in them, but there is wholly a unity in the Divine Persons.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:6
verses.text: Therefore the Son is not to be severed from the Father, especially as they dare not deny that worship is due to Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:7
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:8
verses.text: But the Arians maintain the following: If you say that, as the Father is the only true God, so also is the Son, and confess that the Father and the Son are both of one substance, you introduce not one God, but two.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:9
verses.text: For they who are of one substance seem not to be one God but two Gods.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:10
verses.text: Just as two men or two sheep or more are spoken of, but a man and a sheep are not spoken of as two men or two sheep, but as one man and one sheep.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:11
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:12
verses.text: This is what the Arians say; and by this cunning argument they attempt to catch the more simple-minded.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:13
verses.text: However if we read the divine Scriptures we shall find that plurality occurs rather amongst those things which are of a diverse and different substance, that is, ἑτερούσια.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:14
verses.text: We have this set forth in the books of Solomon, in that passage in which he said: "There are three things impossible to understand, yea, a fourth which I know not, the track of an eagle in the air, the way of a serpent upon a rock, the path of a ship in the sea, and the way of a man in his youth".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:15
verses.text: An eagle and a ship and a serpent are not of one family and nature, but of a distinguishable and different substance, and yet they are three.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:16
verses.text: On the testimony of Scripture, therefore, they learn that their arguments are against themselves.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:17
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:18
verses.text: Therefore, in saying that the substance of the Father and of the Son is diverse and their Godhead distinguishable, they themselves assert there are two Gods.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:19
verses.text: But we, when we confess the Father and the Son, in declaring them still to be of one Godhead, say that there are not two Gods, but one God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:20
verses.text: And this we establish by the word of the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:21
verses.text: For where there are several, there is a difference either of nature or of will and work.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:22
verses.text: Lastly, that they may be refuted on their own witness, two men are mentioned: But though they are of one nature by right of birth, yet in time and thought and work and place, they are apart; and so one man cannot be spoken of under the signification and number of two; for there is no unity where there is diversity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:23
verses.text: But God is said to be one, and the glory and completeness of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit is thus expressed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:24
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:25
verses.text: Such, indeed, is the truth of unity that, when the nature alone of human birth or of human flesh is indicated, one man is the term used for the many, as it is written: "The Lord is my helper, I will not fear what man can do unto me;" that is, not the one person of a man, but the one flesh, the one frailty of human birth.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:26
verses.text: It added also: "It is better to trust in the Lord than to trust in man".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:27
verses.text: Here, too, it did not denote one particular man, but a universal condition.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:28
verses.text: Then, immediately after it added, speaking of many: "It is better to put confidence in the Lord than to put confidence in princes".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:29
verses.text: Where man is spoken of, as we have already said, there the common unity of the nature, which exists between all is indicated; but where the princes are mentioned, there is a certain distinction between their different powers.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:30
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:31
verses.text: Amongst men, or in men, there exists a unity in some one thing, either in love, or desire, or flesh, or devotion, or faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:32
verses.text: But a universal unity, that embraces within itself all things agreeably to the divine glory, is the property of the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit alone.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:33
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:34
verses.text: Wherefore the Lord also, in pointing out the diversity that exists among men, who have nothing in common that can tend towards the unity of an indivisible substance, says: "In your law it is written that the testimony of two men is true".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:35
verses.text: But though He had said, "The testimony of two men is true," when He came to the testimony of Himself and His Father, He said not: "Our testimony is true, for it is the testimony of two Gods;" but: "I am One that bear witness of Myself, and the Father that sent Me beareth witness of Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:36
verses.text: Earlier He also says: "If I judge, My judgment is true; for I am not alone, but I and the Father that sent Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:37
verses.text: Thus, both in one place and the other, He indicated both the Father and the Son, but neither implied the plurality, nor severed the unity of their divine Substance.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:38
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:39
verses.text: It is plain, then, that whatsoever is of one substance cannot be severed, even though it be not single, but one.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:40
verses.text: By singleness I mean that which the Greeks call μονοτής.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:41
verses.text: Singleness has to do with a person; unity with a nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:42
verses.text: That those things which are of a different substance are wont to be called, not one alone, but many, though already proved on the testimony of the prophet, the Apostle himself has stated in so many words, saying: "For though there be that are called gods, whether in heaven or in earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:43
verses.text: Dost thou see, then, that those who are of different substances, and not of the verity of one nature, are called "gods"? But the Father and the Son, being of one substance, are not two Gods, but "One God, the Father, of Whom are all things, and one Lord Jesus Christ, through Whom are all things".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:44
verses.text: "One God," he says, "and one Lord Jesus;" and above: "One God, not two Gods;" and then: "One Lord, not two Lords".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:45
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:46
verses.text: Plurality, therefore, is excluded, but the unity is not destroyed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:47
verses.text: But as, on the one hand, when we read of the Lord Jesus, we do not dissociate the Father, as I have already said, from the prerogative of ruling, because He has that in common with the Son; so, on the other hand, when we read of the only true God, the Father, we cannot sever the Son from the prerogative of the only true God, for He has that in common with the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:48
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:49
verses.text: Let them say what they feel or what they think, when we read: "Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and Him only shalt thou serve".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:50
verses.text: Do they think Christ should not be worshipped, and that He ought not to be served? But if that woman of Canaan who worshipped Him, merited to gain what she asked for, and the Apostle Paul, who confessed himself to be the servant of Christ in the very outset of his letters, merited to be an Apostle "not of men, neither by man, but by Jesus Christ;" let them say what they think should follow.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 3:51
verses.text: Would they prefer to join with Arius in a league of treachery, and so show, by denying Christ to be the only true God, that  they consider He should neither be worshipped nor served? Or would they sooner go in company with Paul, who in serving and worshipping Christ did not disown in word and heart the only true God, Whom he acknowledged with dutiful service?.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:1
verses.text: Chapter IV.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:2
verses.text: It is objected by heretics that Christ offered worship to His Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:3
verses.text: But instead it is shown that this must be referred to His humanity, as is clear from an examination of the passage.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:4
verses.text: However, it also offers fresh witness to His Godhead, as we often see it happening in other actions that Christ did.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:5
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:6
verses.text: But if any one were to say that the Son worships God the Father, because it is written, "Ye worship ye know not what, we know what we worship," let him consider when it was said, and to whom, and to whose wishes it was in answer.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:7
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:8
verses.text: In the earlier verses of this chapter it was stated, not without reason, that Jesus, being weary with the journey, was sitting down, and that He asked a woman of Samaria to give Him drink; for He spoke as man; for as God He could neither be weary nor thirst.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:9
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:10
verses.text: So when this woman addressed Him as a Jew, and thought Him a prophet, He answers her, as a Jew who spiritually taught the mysteries of the Law: "Ye worship ye know not what, we know what we worship".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:11
verses.text: "We," He says; for He joined Himself with men.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:12
verses.text: But how is He joined with men, but according to the flesh? And to show that He answered as being incarnate, He added: "for salvation is of the Jews".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:13
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:14
verses.text: But immediately after this He put aside His human feelings, saying: "But the hour cometh, and now is, when the true worshippers shall worship the Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:15
verses.text: He said not: "We shall worship".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:16
verses.text: This He would certainly have said, if He had a share in our obedience.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:17
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:18
verses.text: And when we read that Mary worshipped Him, we ought to learn that it is not possible for Him under the same nature both to worship as a servant, and to be worshipped as Lord; but rather that as man He is said to worship among men, and that as Lord He is worshipped by His servants.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:19
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:20
verses.text: Many things therefore we read and believe, in the light of the sacrament of the Incarnation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:21
verses.text: But even in the very feelings of our human nature we may behold the Divine Majesty.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 4:22
verses.text: Jesus is wearied with His journey, that He may refresh the weary; He desires to drink, when about to give spiritual drink to the thirsty; He was hungry, when about to supply the food of salvation to the hungry; He dies, to live again; He is buried, to rise again; He hangs upon the dreadful tree, to strengthen those in dread; He veils the heaven with thick darkness, that He may give light; He makes the earth to shake, that He may make it strong; He rouses the sea, that He may calm it; He opens the tombs of the dead, that He may show they are the homes of the living; He is made of a Virgin, that men may believe He is born of God; He feigns not to know, that He may make the ignorant to know; as a Jew He is said to worship, that the Son may be worshipped as true God.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:1
verses.text: Chapter V.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:2
verses.text: Ambrose answers those who press the words of the Lord to the mother of Zebedee's children, by saying that they were spoken out of kindness, because Christ was unwilling to cause her grief.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:3
verses.text: Ample reason for such tenderness is brought forward.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:4
verses.text: The Lord would rather leave the granting of that request to the Father, than declare it to be impossible.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:5
verses.text: This answer of Christ's, however, is not to His detriment, as is shown both by His very words, and also by comparing them with other passages.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:6
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:7
verses.text: "How," they say, "can the Son of God be the only true God, like to the Father, when He Himself said to the sons of Zebedee: 'Ye shall drink indeed of My cup; but to sit on My right hand or on My left, is not Mine to give to you, but to those for whom it has been prepared of My Father'?" This, then, is, as you desire, your proof of divine inequality; though in it you ought rather to reverence the Lord's kindness and to adore His grace; if, that is, you could but perceive the deep secrets of the virtue and wisdom of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:8
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:9
verses.text: For think of her who, with and for her sons, makes this request.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:10
verses.text: It is a mother, who in her anxiety for the honour of her sons, though somewhat unrestrained in the measure of her desires, may for all that yet find pardon.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:11
verses.text: It is a mother, old in years, devout in her zeal, deprived of consolation; who at that time, when she might have been helped and supported by the aid of her able bodied offspring, suffered her children to leave her, and preferred the reward her sons should receive in following  Christ to her own pleasure.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:12
verses.text: For they when called by the Lord, at the first word, as we read, left their nets and their father and followed Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:13
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:14
verses.text: She then, somewhat yielding to the devotion of a mother's zeal, besought the Saviour, saying: "Grant that these my two sons may sit the one on Thy right hand, the other on Thy left in Thy kingdom".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:15
verses.text: Although it was an error, it was an error of a mother's affections; for a mother's heart knows no patience.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:16
verses.text: Though eager for the object of her desires, yet her longing was pardonable, for she was not greedy for money, but for grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:17
verses.text: Not shameless was her request, for she thought not of herself, but of her children.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:18
verses.text: Contemplate the mother, reflect upon her.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:19
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:20
verses.text: But it is nothing wonderful if the feelings of parents for their children seem nothing to you, who think the love of the Almighty Father for His only-begotten Son a trifling matter.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:21
verses.text: The Lord of heaven and earth was ashamed (to speak as accords with the assumption of our flesh and the virtues of the soul)—He was ashamed, I say, and, to use His own word, disturbed, to refuse a share even in His own seat to a mother making request for her sons.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:22
verses.text: You maintain sometimes that the proper Son of the eternal God stands to give service, at other times you would have His co-session to be as that of an attendant, that is, not because there is a oneness of majesty, but because it is the order of the Father; and you deny to the Son of God, Who is true God, that which He plainly was unwilling to refuse to men.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:23
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:24
verses.text: For He thought of the mother's love, who solaced her old age with the thought of her sons' reward, and, though harassed with a mother's longings, endured the absence of those dearest pledges of her love.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:25
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:26
verses.text: Think also of the woman, that is, the weaker sex, whom the Lord had not yet strengthened by His own Passion.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:27
verses.text: Think, I say, of a descendant of Eve, the first woman, sinking under the inheritance of unrestrained passion, which had been passed on to all; one, too, whom the Lord had not yet redeemed with His own Blood, and from whom He had not yet washed out in His Blood the desire implanted in the hearts of all for unbounded honour even beyond what is right.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:28
verses.text: Thus the woman offended owing to an inherited tendency to wrong.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:29
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:30
verses.text: And what wonder if a mother should strive to win preference for her children (which is far better than if she had done it for herself), when even the Apostles themselves, as we read, strove amongst themselves, as to who should have the preference?  61.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:31
verses.text: The physician, therefore, ought not to wound a mother who has been deprived of all, nor a suffering mind, with shameful reproaches, lest when the request had been made and had been proudly denied, she should grieve over the condemnation of her petition as being unreasonable.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:32
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:33
verses.text: Lastly, the Lord, Who knew that a mother's affection is to be honoured, answered not the woman, but her sons, saying: "Are ye able to drink of the cup that I shall drink of?" When they say: "We are able," Jesus says to them: "Ye shall drink indeed of My cup; but to sit on My right hand and on My left is not Mine to give to you, but to those for whom it is prepared of My Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:34
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:35
verses.text: How patient and kind the Lord is; how deep is His wisdom and good His love! For wishing to show that the disciples asked for no slight thing, but one they could not obtain, He reserved His own peculiar rights for His Father's honour, not fearing to detract aught from His own rights: "Who thought it not robbery to be equal with God;" and loving, too, His disciples (for "He loved them," as it is written, "unto the end"), He was unwilling to seem to refuse to those whom He loved what they desired; He, I say, the good and holy Lord, Who would rather keep some of His own prerogative secret, than lay aside aught of His love.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:36
verses.text: "For charity suffereth long, and is kind; charity envieth not, and seeketh not her own".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:37
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:38
verses.text: Lastly, that you may learn it was no sign of weakness, but rather of tenderness, that He said: "It is not Mine to give to you;" note that when the sons of Zebedee make the request without their mother, He said nothing about the Father; for thus it is written: "It is not Mine to give to you, but those for whom it has been prepared".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:39
verses.text: So the Evangelist Mark has stated it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:40
verses.text: But when the mother makes this request on her sons' behalf, as we find it in Matthew, He says: "It is not Mine to give to you, but to those for whom it has been prepared of My Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:41
verses.text: Here He added: "of My Father," for a mother's feelings demanded greater tenderness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:42
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:43
verses.text: But if they think that by saying,  "For whom it hath been prepared of My Father," He assigned greater power to His Father, or detracted aught from His own; let them say whether they think there is any detraction from the Father's power, because the Son in the Gospel says of the Father: "The Father judgeth no man".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:44
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:45
verses.text: But if we think it impious to believe that the Father has handed over all judgment to the Son in such wise that He has it not Himself,—for He has it, and cannot lose what the Divine Majesty has by its very nature,—we ought to consider it equally impious to suppose that the Son cannot give what either men can merit, or any creature can receive; especially as He Himself has said: "I go unto My Father, and whatsoever ye shall ask of Him in My name, that will I do".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:46
verses.text: For if the Son cannot give what the Father can give, the Truth has lied, and cannot do what the Father has been asked for in His name.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:47
verses.text: He therefore did not say: "For whom it has been prepared of My Father," in order that requests should be made only of the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:48
verses.text: For all things which are asked of the Father, He has declared that He will give.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 5:49
verses.text: Lastly, He did not say: "Whatsoever ye shall ask of Me, that will I do;" but: "Whatsoever ye shall ask of Him in My name, that will I do".

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:1
verses.text: Chapter VI.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:2
verses.text: Wishing to answer the above-stated objection somewhat more fully, he maintains that this request, had it not been impossible in itself, would have been possible for Christ to grant; especially as the Father has given all judgment to Him; which gift we must understand to have been given without any feature of imperfection.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:3
verses.text: However, he proves that the request must be reckoned amongst the impossibilities.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:4
verses.text: To make it really possible, he teaches that Christ's answer must be taken in accordance with His human nature, and shows this next by an exposition of the passage.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:5
verses.text: Lastly, he once more confirms the reply he has given on the impossibility of Christ's session.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:6
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:7
verses.text: I ask now whether they think the request made by the wife and sons of Zebedee was possible or impossible to human circumstances, or to any created being? If it was possible, how is it that He Who made all things which were not had not the power of granting a seat to His apostles on His right hand and on His left? or how was it that He, to Whom the Father gave all judgment, could not judge of men's merits?  68.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:8
verses.text: We know well in what way He gave it; for how did the Son, who created all things out of nothing, receive it as though in want? Had He not the judgment of those whose natures He had made? The Father gave all judgment to the Son, "that all men should honour the Son, even as they honour the Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:9
verses.text: It is not therefore the power of the Son, but our knowledge of it, that increases; nor does what is learnt by us add aught to His being, but only to our advantage; so that by knowing the Son of God, we may have eternal life.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:10
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:11
verses.text: As, then, in our knowledge of the Son of God His honour, but our profit, not His, is concerned; if any one thinks that the power of God is augmented by that honour, He must also believe that God the Father can receive augmentation; for He is glorified by our knowledge of Him, as is the Son: as it is written on the word of the Son: "I have glorified Thee upon the earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:12
verses.text: Therefore if that which was asked for was at all possible, it certainly was in the power of the Son to grant it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:13
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:14
verses.text: Let them show, if they consider it possible, who of men or of other created beings sits either on the right hand or the left of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:15
verses.text: For the Father says to the Son: "Sit Thou on My right hand".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:16
verses.text: Therefore if any one sits on the right hand of the Son, the Son is found to be sitting (to speak in human wise) between Himself and the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:17
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:18
verses.text: A thing impossible for man, then, was asked of Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:19
verses.text: But He was unwilling to say that men could not sit with Him; seeing that He desired His divine glory should be veiled, and not revealed before He rose again.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:20
verses.text: For before this, when He had appeared in glory between His attendants Moses and Elias, He had warned His disciples that they should tell no man what they had seen.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:21
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:22
verses.text: Therefore if it was not possible for men or other created beings to merit this, the Son ought not to seem to have less power because He gave not to His apostles, what the Father has not given to men or other created beings.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:23
verses.text: Or else let them say to which of them He has given it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:24
verses.text: Certainly not to the angels; of whom Scripture says that all the angels stood round about the throne.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:25
verses.text: Thus Gabriel said that he stands, as it says: "I am Gabriel that stand before God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:26
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:27
verses.text: Not to the angels, then, has He given it, nor to the elders who worship Him that sitteth; for they do not sit upon the seat of  majesty, but as the Scripture has said, round about the throne; for there are four and twenty other seats, as we have it in the Revelation of John: "And upon the seats four and twenty elders sitting".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:28
verses.text: In the Gospel also the Lord Himself says: "When the Son of Man shall sit in the throne of His glory, ye also shall sit upon twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:29
verses.text: He did not say that a share in His own throne could be given to the apostles, but that there were those other twelve thrones; which, however, we ought not to think of as referring to actual sitting down, but as showing the happy issue of spiritual grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:30
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:31
verses.text: Lastly, in the Book of the Kings, Micaiah the prophet said: "I saw the Lord God of Israel sitting on His throne, and all the host of heaven standing around Him, on His right hand and on His left".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:32
verses.text: How then, when the angels stand on the right hand and on the left of the Lord God, when all the host of heaven stands, shall men sit on the right hand of God or on His left, to whom is promised as a reward for virtue likeness to the angels, as the Lord says: "Ye shall be as the angels in heaven?" "As the angels," He says, not "more than the angels".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:33
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:34
verses.text: If, then, the Father has given nothing more than the Son, the Son certainly has given nothing less than the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:35
verses.text: Therefore the Son can in no wise be less than the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:36
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:37
verses.text: Suppose, however, that it had been possible for men to obtain what was desired; what does it mean when He says: "But to sit on My right hand and on My left is not Mine to give to you"? What is "Mine"? Above He said: "Ye shall drink indeed of My cup;" and again He added: "It is not Mine to give to you".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:38
verses.text: Above He said "Mine," and again lower down He said "Mine".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:39
verses.text: He made no change.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:40
verses.text: And so the earlier passages tell us why He said "Mine".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:41
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:42
verses.text: For being asked by a woman as man to allow her sons to sit on His right hand and His left, because she asked Him as man, the Lord also as though only man answered concerning His Passion: "Are ye able to drink of the cup that I shall drink of?"  78.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:43
verses.text: Therefore because He spoke according to the flesh of the Passion of His Body, He wished to show that according to the flesh He left behind Him an example and pattern to us of the endurance of suffering; but that according to His position as man He could not grant them fellowship in the throne above.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:44
verses.text: This is the reason why He said: "It is not Mine;" as also in another place He says: "My doctrine is not Mine".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:45
verses.text: It is not, He says, spoken after my flesh; for the words which are divine belong not to the flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:46
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:47
verses.text: But how plainly He showed His tenderness for His disciples, whom He loved, saying first: "Will ye drink of My cup?" For as He could not grant what they sought, He offered them something else, so that He might mention what He would assign to them, before He denied them anything; in order that they might understand that the failure lay more in the equity of their request to Him, than in the wish of their Lord to show kindness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:48
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:49
verses.text: "Ye shall indeed drink of My cup," He says; that is, "I will not refuse you the suffering, which My flesh will undergo.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:50
verses.text: For all that I have taken on Myself as man, ye can imitate.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:51
verses.text: I have granted you the victory of suffering, the inheritance of the cross.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:52
verses.text: 'But to sit on My right hand and on My left is not Mine to give to you.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:53
verses.text: '" He did not say, "It is not Mine to give," but: "It is not Mine to give to you;" meaning by this, not that He lacked the power, but that His creatures were wanting in merit.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:54
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:55
verses.text: Or take in another way the words: "It is not Mine to give to you," that is, "It is not Mine, for I came to teach humility; it is not Mine, for I came, not to be ministered unto, but to minister; it is not Mine, for I show justice, not favour".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:56
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:57
verses.text: Then, speaking of the Father, He added: "For whom it has been prepared," to show that the Father also is not wont to give heed merely to requests, but to merits; for God is not a respecter of persons.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:58
verses.text: Wherefore also the Apostle says: "Whom He did foreknow, He also did predestinate".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:59
verses.text: He did not predestinate them before He knew them, but He did predestinate the reward of those whose merits He foreknew.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:60
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:61
verses.text: Rightly then is the woman checked, who demanded what was impossible, as a special kind of privilege from Him the Lord, Who of His own free gift granted not only to two apostles, but to all the disciples, those things which He had adjudged to be given to the saints; and that too without a prayer from any one, as it is written: "Ye shall sit upon twelve thrones, judging the twelve tribes of Israel".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:62
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:63
verses.text: Therefore, although we may think the  demand to have been possible, there is no room for false attacks.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:64
verses.text: However, when I read that the seraphim stand, how can I suppose that men may sit on the right hand or the left of the Son of God? The Lord sits upon the cherubim, as it says: "Thou that sittest upon the cherubim, show myself".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:65
verses.text: And how shall the apostles sit upon the cherubim?  85.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:66
verses.text: And I do not come to this conclusion of my own mind, but because of the utterances of our Lord's own mouth.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:67
verses.text: For the Lord Himself later on, in commending the apostles to the Father, says: "Father, I will that they also whom Thou hast given Me be with Me where I am".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:68
verses.text: But if He had thought that the Father would give the divine throne to men, He would have said: "I will that where I sit, they also may sit with Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:69
verses.text: But He says: "I will that they be with Me," not "that they may sit with Me;" and "where I am," not "as I am".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:70
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:71
verses.text: Then follow the words: "That they may see My glory".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:72
verses.text: Here too He did not say: "that they may have My glory," but "that they may see" it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:73
verses.text: For the servant sees, the Lord possesses; as David also has taught us, saying: "That I may see the delight of the Lord".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:74
verses.text: And the Lord Himself in the Gospel has revealed it, stating: "Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:75
verses.text: "They shall see," He says; not "They shall sit with God upon the cherubim".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:76
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:77
verses.text: Let them therefore cease to think little of the Son of God according to His Godhead, lest they should think little also of the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:78
verses.text: For he who believes wrongly of the Son cannot think rightly of the Father; he who thinks wrongly of the Spirit cannot think rightly of the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:79
verses.text: For where there is one dignity, one glory, one love, one majesty, whatsoever thou thinkest is to be withdrawn in the case of any one of the Three Persons, is withdrawn from all alike.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 6:80
verses.text: For that can never have completeness which thou canst separate and divide into various portions.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7
