verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:1
verses.text: Chapter VII.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:2
verses.text: Objection is taken to the following passage: "Thou hast loved them, as Thou hast loved Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:3
verses.text: To remove it, he shows first the impiety of the Arian explanation; then compares these words with others; and lastly, takes the whole passage into consideration.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:4
verses.text: Hence he gathers that the mission of Christ, although it is to be received according to the flesh, is not to His detriment.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:5
verses.text: When this is proved he shows how the divine mission takes place.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:6
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:7
verses.text: There are some, O Emperor Augustus, who in their desire to deny the unity of the divine Substance, strive to make little of the love of the Father and the Son, because it is written: "Thou hast loved them, as Thou hast loved Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:8
verses.text: But when they say this, what else do they do but adopt a likeness of comparison between the Son of God and men?  89.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:9
verses.text: Can men indeed be loved by God as the Son is, in Whom the Father is well-pleased? He is well-pleasing in Himself; we through Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:10
verses.text: For those in whom God sees His own Son after His own likeness, He admits through His Son into the favour of sons.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:11
verses.text: So that as we go through likeness unto likeness, so through the Generation of the Son are we called unto adoption.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:12
verses.text: The eternal love of God's Nature is one thing, that of grace is another.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:13
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:14
verses.text: And if they start a debate on the words that are written: "And Thou hast loved them, as Thou hast loved Me," and think a comparison is intended; they must think that the following also was said by way of comparison: "Be ye merciful, as your Father Which is in heaven is merciful;" and elsewhere: "Be ye perfect, as My Father Which is in heaven is perfect".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:15
verses.text: But if He is perfect in the fulness of His glory, we are but perfect according to the growth of virtue within us.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:16
verses.text: The Son also is loved by the Father according to the fulness of a love that ever abideth, but in us growth in grace merits the love of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:17
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:18
verses.text: Thou seest, then, how God has given grace to men, and dost thou wish to dissever the natural and indivisible love of the Father and the Son? And dost thou still strive to make nothing of words, where thou dost note the mention of a unity of majesty?  92.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:19
verses.text: Consider the whole of this passage, and see from what standpoint He speaks; for thou hearest Him saying: "Father, glorify Thou Me with the glory which I had with Thee before the world was".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:20
verses.text: See how He speaks from the standpoint of the first man.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:21
verses.text: For He begs for us in that request those things which, as Man, He remembered were granted in paradise before the Fall, as also He spoke of it to the thief at His Passion: "Verily, verily, I say unto thee, today shalt thou be with Me in paradise".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:22
verses.text: This is the glory before the world was.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:23
verses.text: But He used the word "world" instead "men," as also thou hast it: "Lo! the whole world goeth after Him;" and again "That the world may know that Thou hast sent Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:24
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:25
verses.text: But that thou mightest know the great God, even the life-giving and Almighty Son of God, He has added a proof of His majesty by saying: "And all Mine are Thine, and Thine are Mine".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:26
verses.text: He has all things, and dost thou turn aside the fact that He was sent, to wrong Him?  94.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:27
verses.text: But if thou dost not accept the truth of His mission according to the flesh, as the Apostle spoke of it, and dost raise out of a mere word a decision against it, to enable thee to say that inferiors are wont to be sent by superiors; what answer wilt thou give to the fact that the Son was sent to men? For if thou dost think that he who is sent is inferior to him by whom he is sent, thou must learn also that an inferior has sent a superior, and that superiors have been sent to inferiors.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:28
verses.text: For Tobias sent Raphael the archangel, and an angel was sent to Balaam, and the Son of God to the Jews.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:29
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:30
verses.text: Or was the Son of God inferior to the Jews to whom He was sent? For of Him it is written: "Last of all He sent unto them His only Son, saying, They will reverence My Son".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:31
verses.text: And mark that He mentioned first the servants, then the Son, that thou mayest know that God, the only-begotten Son according to the power of His Godhead, has neither name nor lot in common with servants.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:32
verses.text: He is sent forth to be reverenced, not to be compared with the household.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:33
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:34
verses.text: And rightly did He add the word "My," that we might believe He came, not as one of many, nor as one of a lower nature or of some inferior power, but as true from Him that is true, as the Image of the Father's Substance.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:35
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:36
verses.text: Suppose, however, that he who is sent is inferior to him by whom he is sent.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:37
verses.text: Christ then was inferior to Pilate; for Pilate sent Him to Herod.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:38
verses.text: But a word does not prejudice His power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:39
verses.text: Scripture, which says that He was sent from the Father, says that He was sent from a ruler.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:40
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:41
verses.text: Wherefore, if we sensibly hold to those things which be worthy of the Son of God, we ought to understand Him to have been sent in such a way that the Word of God, out of the incomprehensible and ineffable mystery of the depths of His majesty, gave Himself for comprehension to our minds, so far as we could lay hold of Him, not only when He "emptied" Himself, but also when He dwelt in us, as it is written: "I will dwell in them".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:42
verses.text: Elsewhere also it stands that God said: "Go to, let us go down and confound their language".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:43
verses.text: God, indeed, never descends from any place; for He says: "I fill heaven and earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:44
verses.text: But He seems to descend when the Word of God enters our hearts, as the prophet has said: "Prepare ye the way of the Lord, make His paths straight".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:45
verses.text: We are to do this, so that, as He Himself promised, He may come together with the Father and make His abode with us.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 7:46
verses.text: It is clear, then, how He comes.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:1
verses.text: Chapter VIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:2
verses.text: Christ, so far as He is true Son of God, has no Lord, but only so far as He is Man; as is shown by His words in which He addressed at one time the Father, at another the Lord.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:3
verses.text: How many heresies are silenced by one verse of Scripture! We must distinguish between the things that belong to Christ as Son of God or as Son of David.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:4
verses.text: For under the latter title only must we ascribe it to Him that He was a servant.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:5
verses.text: Lastly, he points out that many passages cannot be taken except as referring to the Incarnation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:6
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:7
verses.text: Wherefore also it is plain how He calls Him Lord, Whom He knew as Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:8
verses.text: For He says: "I confess to Thee, Father, Lord of heaven and earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:9
verses.text: First Wisdom spoke of His own Father, and then proclaimed Him Lord of creation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:10
verses.text: For this reason the Lord shows in His Gospel that no lordship is exercised where there is a true offspring, saying: "What think ye of Christ? Whose Son is He? They say unto Him, The son of David.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:11
verses.text: Jesus saith to them, How then doth David in spirit call Him Lord, saying: The Lord said unto my Lord: Sit Thou on My right hand"? Then he added: "If David in spirit then call Him Lord, how is He his son? And no man was able to answer Him a word".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:12
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:13
verses.text: With what care did the Lord provide for the faith in this witness because of the Arians! For He did not say: "The spirit calls Him Lord," but that "David spake in spirit;" in order that men might believe that as He is his, that is, David's son according to the flesh, so also He is his Lord and God according to His Godhead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:14
verses.text: Thou seest, then, that there is a distinction between the  titles that are used of relationship and of lordship.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:15
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:16
verses.text: And rightly did the Lord speak of His own Father, but of the Lord of heaven and earth; so that thou, when thou readest of the Father and the Lord, mayest understand it is the Father of the Son, and the Lord of Creation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:17
verses.text: In the one title rests the claim of nature, in the other the authority to rule.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:18
verses.text: For taking on Himself the form of a servant, He calls Him Lord, because He has submitted to service; being equal to Him in the form of God, but being a servant in the form of His body: for service is the due of the flesh, but lordship is the due of the Godhead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:19
verses.text: Wherefore also the Apostle says: "The God of our Lord Jesus Christ, the Father of glory," that is, terming Him God of the adoption of humanity but the Father of glory.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:20
verses.text: Did God have two Sons, Christ and Glory? Certainly not.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:21
verses.text: Therefore if there is one Son of God, even Christ, Christ is Glory.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:22
verses.text: Why dost thou strive to belittle Him who is the glory of the Father?  102.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:23
verses.text: If then the Son is glory, and the Father is glory (for the Father of glory cannot be anything else than glory), there is no separation of glories, but glory is one.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:24
verses.text: Thus glory is referred to its own proper nature, but lordship to the service of the body that was assumed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:25
verses.text: For if the flesh is subject to the soul of a just man as it is written: "I chastise my body and bring it into subjection;" how much more is it subject to the Godhead, of Which it is said: "For all things serve Thee"?  103.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:26
verses.text: By one question the Lord has shut out both Sabellians and Photinians and Arians.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:27
verses.text: For when He said that the Lord spoke to the Lord, Sabellius is set aside, who will have it that the same Person is both Father and Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:28
verses.text: Photinus is set aside, who thinks of Him merely as man; for none could be Lord of David the King, but He Who is God, for it is written: "Thou shalt worship the Lord thy God, and Him only shalt thou serve".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:29
verses.text: Would the prophet who ruled under the Law act contrary to the Law? Arius is set aside, who hears that the Son sits on the right hand of the Father; so that if he argues from human ways, he refutes himself, and makes the poison of his blasphemous arguments to flow back upon himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:30
verses.text: For in interpreting the inequality of the Father and the Son by the analogy of human habits (wandering from the truth in either case), he puts Him first Whom he makes little of, confessing Him to be the First, Whom he hears to be at the right hand.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:31
verses.text: The Manichaean also is set aside, for he does not deny that He is the Son of David according to the flesh, Who, at the cry of the blind men, "Jesus, Thou Son of David, have mercy on us," was pleased at their faith and stood and healed them.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:32
verses.text: But He does deny that this refers to His eternity, if He is called Son of David alone by those who are false.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:33
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:34
verses.text: For "Son of God" is against Ebion, "Son of David," is against the Manichees; "Son of God" is against Photinus, "Son of David" is against Marcion; "Son of God" is against Paul of Samosata, "Son of David" is against Valentinus; "Son of God" is against Arius and Sabellius, the inheritors of heathen errors.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:35
verses.text: "Lord of David" is against the Jews, who beholding the Son of God in the flesh, in impious madness believed Him to be only man.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:36
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:37
verses.text: But in the faith of the Church one and the same is both Son of God the Father and Son of David.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:38
verses.text: For the mystery of the Incarnation of God is the salvation of the whole of creation, according to that which is written: "That without God He should taste death for every man;" that is, that every creature might be redeemed without any suffering at the price of the blood of the Lord's Divinity, as it stands elsewhere: "Every creature shall be delivered from the bondage of corruption".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:39
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:40
verses.text: It is one thing to be named Son according to the divine Substance, it is another thing to be so called according to the adoption of human flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:41
verses.text: For, according to the divine Generation, the Son is equal to God the Father; and, according to the adoption of a body, He is a servant to God the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:42
verses.text: "For," it says, "He took upon Him the form of a servant".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:43
verses.text: The Son is, however, one and the same.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:44
verses.text: On the other hand, according to His glory, He is Lord to the holy patriarch David, but his Son in the line of actual descent, not abandoning aught of His own, but acquiring for Himself the rights that go with the adoption into our race.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:45
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:46
verses.text: Not only does He undergo service in the character of man by reason of His descent from David, but also by reason of His name, as it is written: "I have found David My Servant;" and elsewhere: "Behold I  will send unto you My Servant, the Orient is His name".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:47
verses.text: And the Son Himself says: "Thus saith the Lord, that formed Me from the womb to be His servant, and said unto Me: It is a great thing for Thee to be called My Servant.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:48
verses.text: Behold I have set Thee up for a witness to My people, and a light to the Gentiles, that Thou mayest be for salvation unto the ends of the earth".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:49
verses.text: To whom is this said, if not to Christ? Who being in the form of God, emptied Himself and took upon Him the form of a servant.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:50
verses.text: But what can be in the form of God, except that which exists in the fulness of the Godhead?  108.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:51
verses.text: Learn, then, what this means: "He took upon Him the form of a servant".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:52
verses.text: It means that He took upon Him all the perfections of humanity in their completeness, and obedience in its completeness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:53
verses.text: And so it says in the thirtieth Psalm: "Thou hast set my feet in a large room.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:54
verses.text: I am made a reproach above all mine enemies.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:55
verses.text: Make Thy face to shine upon Thy servant".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:56
verses.text: "Servant" means the Man in whom He was sanctified; it means the Man in whom He was anointed; it means the Man in whom He was made under the law, made of the Virgin; and, to put it briefly, it means the Man in whose person He has a mother, as it is written: "O Lord, I am Thy Servant, I am Thy Servant, and the Son of Thy hand-maid;" and again: "I am cast down and sore humbled".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:57
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:58
verses.text: Who is sore humbled, but Christ, Who came to free all through His obedience? "For as by one man's disobedience many were made sinners, so by the obedience of one shall many be made righteous".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:59
verses.text: Who received the cup of salvation? Christ the High Priest, or David who never held the priesthood, nor endured suffering? Who offered the sacrifice of Thanksgiving?  110.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:60
verses.text: But that is insufficient; take again: "Preserve My soul, for I am holy".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:61
verses.text: Did David say this of himself? Nay, He says it, Who also says: "Thou wilt not leave My soul in hell, neither wilt Thou suffer Thine Holy One to see corruption".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:62
verses.text: The Same then says both of these.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:63
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:64
verses.text: He has added further: "Save Thy Servant;" and, further on: "Give Thy strength to Thy servant, and to the Son of Thy handmaid;" and, elsewhere, that is, in Ezekiel: "And I will set up one Shepherd over them, and He shall rule them, even My Servant David.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:65
verses.text: He shall feed them, and He shall be their Shepherd.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:66
verses.text: And I the Lord will be their God, and My Servant David a prince among them".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:67
verses.text: Now David the Son of Jesse was already dead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:68
verses.text: Therefore he speaks of Christ, Who for our sakes was made the Son of a handmaiden in the form of man; for according to His divine Generation He has no Mother, but a Father only: nor is He the fruit of earthly desire, but the eternal Power of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:69
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:70
verses.text: And so, also, when we read that the Lord said: "My time is not yet full come;" and: "Yet a little while I am with you;" and: "I go unto Him that sent Me;" and: "Now is the Son of Man glorified;" we ought to refer all this to the sacrament of the Incarnation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:71
verses.text: But when we read: "And God is glorified in Him, and God hath glorified Him;" what doubt is there here, where the Son is glorified by the Father, and the Father is glorified by the Son?  113.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:72
verses.text: Next, to make clear the faith of the Unity, and the Union of the Trinity, He also said that He would be glorified by the Spirit, as it stands: "He shall receive of Mine, and shall glorify Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:73
verses.text: Therefore the Holy Spirit also glorifies the Son of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:74
verses.text: How, then, did He say: "If I glorify Myself, My glory is nothing".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:75
verses.text: Is then the glory of the Son nothing? It is blasphemy to say so, unless we apply these words to His flesh; for the Son spoke in the character of man, for by comparison with the Godhead, there is no glory of the flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:76
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:77
verses.text: Let them cease from their wicked objections which are but thrown back upon their own falseness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:78
verses.text: For they say, it is written: "Now is the Son of Man glorified".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:79
verses.text: I do not deny that it is written: "The Son of Man is glorified".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:80
verses.text: But let them see what follows: "And God is glorified in Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:81
verses.text: I can plead some excuse for the Son of Man, but He has none for His Father; for the Father took not flesh upon Himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:82
verses.text: I can plead an excuse, but do not use it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:83
verses.text: He has none, and is falsely attacked.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:84
verses.text: I can either understand it in its plain sense, or I can apply to the flesh what concerns the flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:85
verses.text: A devout mind distinguishes between the things which are spoken after the flesh or after the Godhead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 8:86
verses.text: An impious mind turns aside to the dishonour of the Godhead, all that is said with regard to the littleness of the flesh.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:1
verses.text: Chapter IX.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:2
verses.text: The saint meets those who in Jewish wise object to the order of the words: "In the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost," with the retort that the Son also is often placed before the Father; though he first points out that an answer to this objection has been already given by him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:3
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:4
verses.text: Why is it that the Arians, after the Jewish fashion, are such false and shameless interpreters of the divine words, going indeed so far as to say that there is one power of the Father, another of the Son, and another of the Holy Ghost, since it is written: "Go ye, teach all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father and of the Son and of the Holy Ghost"? And why do they make a distinction of divine power owing to the mere order of words?  116.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:5
verses.text: Though I have already given this very witness for a unity of majesty and name in my former books, yet if they make this the ground of debate, I can maintain on the testimony of the Scriptures that the Son is mentioned first in many places, and that the Father is spoken of after Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:6
verses.text: Is it therefore a fact that, because the name of the Son is placed first, by the mere accident of a word, as the Arians would have it, the Father comes second to the Son? God forbid, I say, God forbid.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:7
verses.text: Faith knows nothing of such order as this; it knows nothing of a divided honour of the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:8
verses.text: I have not read of, nor heard of, nor found any varying degree in God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:9
verses.text: Never have I read of a second, never of a third God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:10
verses.text: I have read of a first God, I have heard of a first and only God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:11
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:12
verses.text: If we pay such excessive regard to order, then the Son ought not to sit at the right hand of the Father, nor ought He to call Himself the First and the Beginning.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:13
verses.text: The Evangelist was wrong in beginning with the Word and not with God, where he says: "In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:14
verses.text: For, according to the order of human usage, he ought to name the Father first.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:15
verses.text: The Apostle also was ignorant of their order, who says: "Paul the servant of Jesus Christ, called to be an Apostle, separated unto the Gospel of God;" and elsewhere: "The grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, and the love of God, and the communion of the Holy Ghost".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:16
verses.text: If we follow the order of the words, he has placed the Son first, and the Father second.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 9:17
verses.text: But the order of the words is often changed; and therefore thou oughtest not to question about order or degree, in the case of God the Father and His Son, for there is no severance of unity in the Godhead.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:1
verses.text: Chapter X.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:2
verses.text: The Arians openly take sides with the heathen in attacking the words: "He that believeth on Me, believeth not on Me," etc.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:3
verses.text: The true meaning of the passage is unfolded; and to prevent us from believing that the Lord forbade us to have faith in Him, it is shown how He spoke at one time as God, at another as Man.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:4
verses.text: After bringing forward examples of various results of that faith, he shows that certain other passages also must be taken in the same way.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:5
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:6
verses.text: Last of all, to show that they are not Christians, they deny that we are to believe on Christ, saying that it is written: "He that believeth on Me, believeth not on Me, but on Him that sent Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:7
verses.text: I was awaiting this confession; why did you delude me with your quibbles? I knew I had to contend with heathens.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:8
verses.text: Nay, they indeed are converted, but ye are not.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:9
verses.text: If they believe, that the sacrament [of Baptism] is safe; ye have received it, and destroyed it, or perchance it has never been received, but was unreal from the first.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:10
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:11
verses.text: It is written, they say: "He that believeth on Me, believeth not on Me, but on Him that sent Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:12
verses.text: But see what follows, and see how the Son of God wishes to be seen; for it continues: "And he that seeth Me, seeth Him that sent Me," for the Father is seen in the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:13
verses.text: Thus, He has explained what He had spoken earlier, that he who confesses the Father believes on the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:14
verses.text: For he who knows not the Son, neither knows the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:15
verses.text: For every one that denies the Son has not the Father, but he that confesses the Son has both the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:16
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:17
verses.text: What, then, is the meaning of "Believeth not on Me"? That is, not on that which you can perceive in bodily form, nor merely on the man whom you see.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:18
verses.text: For He has stated that we are to believe not merely on a man, but that thou mayest believe that Jesus Christ Himself is both God and Man.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:19
verses.text: Wherefore, for both reasons He says: "I came not from Myself;" and again: "I am the beginning, of which also I speak to you".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:20
verses.text: As Man He came not from Himself; as Son of God He takes not  His beginning from men; but "I am," He says, "Myself 'the beginning of which also I speak to you.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:21
verses.text: ' Neither are the words which I speak human, but divine".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:22
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:23
verses.text: Nor is it right to believe that He denied we were to believe on Him, since He Himself said: "That whosoever believeth on Me should not abide in darkness;" and in another place again: "For this is the will of My Father that sent Me, that every one that seeth the Son, and believeth on Him, may have eternal life;" and again: "Ye believe in God, believe also in Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:24
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:25
verses.text: Let no one, therefore, receive the Son without the Father, because we read of the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:26
verses.text: The Son hath the Father, but not in a temporal sense, nor by reason of His passion, nor owing to His conception, nor by grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:27
verses.text: I have read of His Generation, I have not read of His Conception.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:28
verses.text: And the Father says: "I have begotten;" He does not say: "I have created".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:29
verses.text: And the Son calls not God His Creator in the eternity of His divine Generation, but Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:30
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:31
verses.text: He represents Himself also now in the character of man, now in the majesty of God; now claiming for Himself oneness of Godhead with the Father, now taking upon Him all the frailty of human flesh; now saying that He has not His own doctrine, and now that He seeks not His own will; now pointing out that His testimony is not true, and now that it is true.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:32
verses.text: For He Himself has said: "If I bear witness of Myself, My witness is not true".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:33
verses.text: Later on He says: "If I bear witness of Myself, My witness is true".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:34
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:35
verses.text: And how is Thy testimony, Lord Jesus, not true? Did not he who believed it, though he hung upon the cross, and paid the penalty for the crime he owned to, cast aside the deserts of the robber and gain the reward of the innocent?  125.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:36
verses.text: Was Paul deceived, who received his sight, because he believed; which sight he had lost, before he believed?  126.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:37
verses.text: And did Joshua, the son of Nun, err in recognizing the leader of the heavenly host? But after he believed, he forthwith conquered, being found worthy to triumph in the battle of faith.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:38
verses.text: Again, he did not lead forth his armed ranks into the fight, nor did he overthrow the ramparts of the enemy's walls, with battering rams or other engines of war, but with the sound of the seven trumpets of the priests.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:39
verses.text: Thus the blare of the trumpet and the badge of the priest brought a cruel war to an end.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:40
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:41
verses.text: A harlot saw this; and she who in the destruction of the city lost all hope of any means of safety, because her faith had conquered, bound a scarlet thread in her window, and thus uplifted a sign of her faith and the banner of the Lord's Passion; so that the semblance of the mystic blood, which should redeem the world, might be in memory.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:42
verses.text: So, without, the name of Joshua was a sign of victory to those who fought; within, the semblance of the Lord's Passion was a sign of salvation to those in danger.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:43
verses.text: Wherefore, because Rahab understood the heavenly mystery, the Lord says in the Psalm: "I will be mindful of Rahab and Babylon that know Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:44
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:45
verses.text: How, then, is Thy testimony not true, O Lord, except it be given in accordance with the frailty of man? For "every man is a liar".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:46
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:47
verses.text: Lastly, to prove that He spoke as man, He says: "The Father that sent Me, He beareth witness of Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:48
verses.text: But His testimony as God is true, as He Himself says: "My record is true: for I know whence I come, and whither I go, but ye know not whence I come, and whither I go.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:49
verses.text: Ye judge after the flesh".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:50
verses.text: They judge then not after the Godhead but after the manhood, who think that Christ had not the power of bearing witness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:51
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:52
verses.text: Therefore, when thou hearest: "He that believeth, believeth not on Me;" or: "The Father that sent Me, He gave Me a commandment;" thou hast now learnt whither thou oughtest to refer those words.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:53
verses.text: Lastly, He shows what the commandment is, saying: "I lay down My life, that I may take it again.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:54
verses.text: No man taketh it from Me, but I lay it down of Myself".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:55
verses.text: Thou seest, then, what is said so as to show He had full power to lay down or to take up His life; as He also said: "I have power to lay it down, and I have power again to take it up.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:56
verses.text: This commandment have I received of My Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:57
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 10:58
verses.text: Whether, then, a command, or, as some Latin manuscripts have it, a direction was given, it was certainly not given to Him as God, but as incarnate man, with reference to the victory He should gain in undergoing His Passion.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:1
verses.text: Chapter XI.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:2
verses.text: We must refer the fact that Christ is said to speak nothing of Himself, to His human nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:3
verses.text: After explaining how it is right to say that He hears and sees the Father as being God, He shows conclusively, by a large number of proofs, that the Son of God is not a creature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:4
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:5
verses.text: Are we indeed to bring the Son of God to such a low estate that He may not know how to act or speak, except as He hears, and are we to suppose that a fixed measure of action or of speech is assigned to Him, because it is written: "I speak not of Myself," and, further on: "As the Father hath said unto Me, even so I speak"? But those words have reference to the obedience of the flesh, or else to the faith in the Unity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:6
verses.text: For many learned men allow that the Son hears, and that the Father speaks to the Son through the unity of their Nature; for that which the Son, through the unity of their will, knows that the Father wills, He seems to have heard.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:7
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:8
verses.text: Whereby is meant no personal duty, but an indivisible sentence of co-operation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:9
verses.text: For this does not signify any actual hearing of words, but the unity of will and of power, which exists both in the Father and in the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:10
verses.text: He has stated that this exists also in the Holy Spirit, in another place, saying, "For He shall not speak of Himself, but whatsoever He shall hear, that shall He speak," so that we may learn that whatsoever the Spirit says, the Son also says; and whatsoever the Son says, the Father says also; for there is one mind and one mode of working in the Trinity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:11
verses.text: For, as the Father is seen in the Son, not indeed in bodily appearance, but in the unity of the Godhead, so also the Father speaks in the Son, not with a voice of earth, not with a human sound, but in the unity of Their work.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:12
verses.text: So when He had said: "The Father that dwelleth in Me, He speaketh; and the works that I do, He doeth;" He added: "Believe Me, that I am in the Father, and the Father in Me; or else believe Me for the very work's sake".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:13
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:14
verses.text: This is what we understand according to the whole course of the holy Scriptures; but the Arians, who will not think of God the things that be right, may be put to silence by an example just suited to their deserts; that they may not believe everything in carnal fashion, since they themselves do not see the works of their father the devil with bodily eyes.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:15
verses.text: So the Lord has declared of their fellows the Jews, saying: "Ye do what ye have seen your father doing;" though they are reproved not because they saw the work of the devil, but because they did his will, since the devil unseen works out sin in them in accordance with their own wickedness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:16
verses.text: We have written this, as the Apostle did, because of the folly of these traitors.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:17
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:18
verses.text: But we have sufficiently proved by examples from Scripture that it is a property of the unity of the divine majesty that the Father should abide in the Son, and that the Son should seem to have heard from the Father those things which He speaks.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:19
verses.text: How else can we understand the unity of majesty than by the knowledge that the same deference is paid to the Father and the Son? For what can be better put than the Apostle's saying that the Lord of glory was crucified?  136.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:20
verses.text: The Son then is the God of glory and the Lord of glory, but glory is not subject to creatures; the Son therefore is not a creature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:21
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:22
verses.text: The Son is the Image of the Father's Substance; but every creature is unlike that divine Substance, but the Son of the Father is not unlike God; therefore the Son is not a creature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:23
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:24
verses.text: The Son thought it not robbery to be equal with God; but no creature is equal with God, the Son, however, is equal; therefore the Son is not a creature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:25
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:26
verses.text: Every creature is changeable; but the Son of God is not changeable; therefore the Son of God is not a creature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:27
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:28
verses.text: Every creature meets with chance occurrences of good and evil after the powers of its nature, and also feels their passing away; but nothing can pass away from or bring addition to the Son of God in His Godhead; therefore the Son of God is not a creature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:29
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:30
verses.text: Every work of His God will bring into judgment; but the Son of God is not brought into judgment; for He Himself judges; therefore the Son of God is not a creature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:31
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:32
verses.text: Lastly, that thou mayest understand the unity, the Saviour in speaking of His sheep says: "No man is able to pluck them out of My hand.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:33
verses.text: My Father Which gave them to Me is greater than all, and no man is able to pluck them out of My Father's hand.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:34
verses.text: I and My Father are one".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:35
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:36
verses.text: So the Son gives life as does the  Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:37
verses.text: "For as the Father raiseth up the dead and quickeneth them, even so the Son quickeneth whom He will".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:38
verses.text: So the Son raises up as does the Father: so too the Son preserves as does the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:39
verses.text: He Who is not unequal in grace, how is He unequal in power? So also the Son does not destroy, as neither does the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:40
verses.text: Therefore lest any one should believe there were two Gods, or should imagine a diversity of power, He said that He was one with His Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:41
verses.text: How can a creature say that? Therefore the Son of God is not a creature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:42
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:43
verses.text: It is not the same thing to rule as to serve; but Christ is both a King and the Son of a King.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:44
verses.text: The Son of God therefore is not a servant.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:45
verses.text: Every creature, however, gives service.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:46
verses.text: But the Son of God, Who makes servants become the sons of God, does not give service.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 11:47
verses.text: Therefore the Son of God is not a servant.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:1
verses.text: Chapter XII.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:2
verses.text: He confirms what has been already said, by the parable of the rich man who went into a far country to receive for himself a kingdom; and shows that when the Son delivers up the kingdom to the Father, we must not regard the fact that the Father is said to put all things in subjection under Him, in a disparaging way.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:3
verses.text: Here we are the kingdom of Christ, and in Christ's kingdom.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:4
verses.text: Hereafter we shall be in the kingdom of God, where the Trinity will reign together.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:5
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:6
verses.text: In divine fashion has He represented that parable of the rich man, who went to a far-off country to receive a kingdom, and to return, thus describing Himself in the substance of the Godhead, and of His Manhood.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:7
verses.text: For He being rich in the fulness of His Godhead, Who was made poor for us though He was rich and an eternal King, and the Son of an eternal King; He, I say, went to a foreign country in taking on Him a body, for He entered upon the ways of men as though upon a strange journey, and came into this world to prepare for Himself a kingdom from amongst us.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:8
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:9
verses.text: Jesus therefore came to this earth to receive for Himself a kingdom from us, to whom He says: "The kingdom of God is within you".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:10
verses.text: This is the kingdom which Christ has received, this the kingdom which He has delivered to the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:11
verses.text: For how did He receive for Himself a kingdom, Who was a King eternal? "The Son of Man therefore came to receive a kingdom and to return".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:12
verses.text: The Jews were unwilling to acknowledge Him, of whom He says: "They which would not that I should reign over them, bring hither and slay them".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:13
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:14
verses.text: Let us follow the course of the Scriptures.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:15
verses.text: He Who came will deliver up the kingdom to God the Father; and when He has delivered up the kingdom, then also shall He be subject to Him, Who has put all things in subjection under Him, that God may be all in all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:16
verses.text: If the Son of God has received the kingdom as Son of Man, surely as Son of Man also He will deliver up what He has received.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:17
verses.text: If He delivers it up as Son of Man, as Son of Man He confesses His subjection indeed under the conditions of the flesh, and not in the majesty of His Godhead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:18
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:19
verses.text: And dost thou make objections and contemn Him, because God has put all things in subjection under Him, when thou hearest that the Son of Man delivers up the kingdom to God, and hast read, as we said in our earlier books: "No man can come to Me, except the Father draw him; and I will raise him up at the last day"? If we follow it literally, see rather and notice the unity of honour each gives to other: The Father has put all things in subjection under the Son, and the Son delivers the kingdom to the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:20
verses.text: Say now which is the greater, to deliver up, or to raise up to life? Do we not after human fashion speak of the service of delivering up, and the power of raising to life? But both the Son delivers up to the Father, and also the Father to the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:21
verses.text: The Son raises to life, and the Father also raises to life.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:22
verses.text: Let them create the fiction of a blasphemous division where there is a unity of power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:23
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:24
verses.text: Let the Son then deliver up His kingdom to the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:25
verses.text: The kingdom which He delivers up is not lost to Christ, but grows.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:26
verses.text: We are the kingdom, for it was said to us: "The kingdom of God is within you".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:27
verses.text: And we are the kingdom, first of Christ, then of the Father; as it is written: "No man cometh to the Father, but by Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:28
verses.text: When I am on the way, I am Christ's; when I have passed through, I am the Father's; but everywhere through Christ, and everywhere under Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:29
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:30
verses.text: It is a good thing to be in the kingdom of Christ, so that Christ may be with us; as He Himself says: "Lo I am with you always, even unto the end of the world".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:31
verses.text: But it is better to be with Christ:  "For to depart and be with Christ is far better".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:32
verses.text: Though we are under sin in this world, Christ is with us, that "by the obedience of one man many may be made just".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:33
verses.text: And if I escape the sin of this world, I shall begin to be with Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:34
verses.text: And so He says: "I will come again, and receive you unto Myself;" and further on: "I will that where I am, there ye may be also with Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:35
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:36
verses.text: Therefore we are now under Christ's rule, whilst we are in the body, and are not yet stripped of the form of a servant, which He put upon Him, when He "emptied Himself".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:37
verses.text: But when we shall see His glory, which He had before the world was, we shall be in the kingdom of God, in which are the patriarchs and prophets, of whom it is written: "When ye shall see Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, and all the prophets in the kingdom of God;" and shall thus acquire a deeper knowledge of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:38
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:39
verses.text: But in the kingdom of the Son the Father also reigns; and in the kingdom of the Father the Son also reigns: for the Father is in the Son, and the Son in the Father; and in whomsoever the Son dwells, in him also the Father dwells; and in whomsoever the Father dwells, in him also the Son dwells, as it is written: "Both I and My Father will come to Him, and make Our abode with Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:40
verses.text: Thus as there is one dwelling, so also there is one kingdom.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:41
verses.text: Yea, and so far is the kingdom of the Father and of the Son but one, that the Father receives what the Son delivers, and the Son does not lose what the Father receives.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:42
verses.text: Thus in the one kingdom there is a unity of power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 12:43
verses.text: Let no one therefore sever the Godhead between the Father and the Son.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:1
verses.text: Chapter XIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:2
verses.text: With the desire to learn what subjection to Christ means after putting forward and rejecting various ideas of subjection, he runs through the Apostle's words; and so puts an end to the blasphemous opinions of the heretics on this matter.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:3
verses.text: The subjection, which is shown to be future, cannot concern the Godhead, since there has always been the greatest harmony of wills between the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:4
verses.text: Also to that same Son in His Godhead all things have indeed been made subject; but they are said to be not yet subject to Him in this sense, because all men do not obey His commands.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:5
verses.text: But after that they have been made subject, then shall Christ also be made subject in them, and the Father's work be perfected.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:6
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:7
verses.text: But if the one name and right of God belong to both the Father and the Son, since the Son of God is also true God, and a King eternal, the Son of God is not made subject in His Godhead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:8
verses.text: Let us then, Emperor Augustus, think how we ought to regard His subjection.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:9
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:10
verses.text: How is the Son of God made subject? As the creature to vanity? But it is blasphemous to have any such idea of the Substance of the Godhead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:11
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:12
verses.text: Or as every creature is to the Son of God, for it is rightly written: "Thou hast put all things in subjection under His feet"? But Christ is not made subject to Himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:13
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:14
verses.text: Or as a woman to a man, as we read: "Let the wives be subject to their husbands;" and again: "Let the woman learn in silence in all subjection"? But it is impious to compare a man to the Father, or a woman to the Son of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:15
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:16
verses.text: Or as Peter said: "Submit yourselves to every human creature"? But Christ was certainly not so subject.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:17
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:18
verses.text: Or as Paul wrote: "Submitting yourselves mutually to God and the Father in the fear of Christ"? But Christ was not subject either in His own fear, nor in the fear of another Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:19
verses.text: For Christ is but one.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:20
verses.text: But note the force of these words, that we are subject to the Father, whilst we also fear Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:21
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:22
verses.text: How, then, do we understand His subjection? Shall we review the whole chapter which the Apostle wrote, so as to give no appearance of having falsely withheld anything, or of having weakened its force with intention to deceive? "If in this life only," he says, "we have hope in Christ, we are of all men most miserable.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:23
verses.text: But if Christ is risen from the dead, He is the first-fruits of them that sleep".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:24
verses.text: Ye see how he discusses the question of Christ's Resurrection.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:25
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:26
verses.text: "For since by one man," he says, "came death, by man came also the resurrection of the dead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:27
verses.text: For as in Adam all die, even so in Christ shall all be made alive.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:28
verses.text: But each one in his own order: Christ the firstfruits; afterward they that are Christ's, who have believed in His coming.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:29
verses.text: Then cometh the end, when He shall have delivered up the kingdom to God, even the Father, when He shall have put down all rule and authority and power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:30
verses.text: For He must reign until He hath put all enemies under His feet.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:31
verses.text: The last enemy that shall be destroyed is death; for He hath put all things under His  feet.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:32
verses.text: But when He saith, all things are put under Him, it is manifest that He is excepted Which did put all things under Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:33
verses.text: But when all things shall be subdued unto Him, then shall the Son also Himself be subject unto Him, that put all things under Him, that God may be all in all".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:34
verses.text: Thus also the same Apostle said to the Hebrews: "But now we see not yet all things put under Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:35
verses.text: We have heard the whole of the Apostle's discourse.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:36
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:37
verses.text: How, then, do we speak of His subjection? The Sabellians and Marcionites say that this subjection of Christ to God the Father will be in such wise that the Son will be re-absorbed into the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:38
verses.text: If, then, the subjection of the Word means that God the Word is to be absorbed into the Father; then whatsoever is made subject to the Father and the Son will be absorbed into the Father and the Son, that God may be all and in all His creatures.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:39
verses.text: But it is foolish to say so.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:40
verses.text: There is therefore no subjection through re-absorption.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:41
verses.text: For there are other things which are made subject, those, that is to say, which are created, and there is Another, to Whom that subjection is made.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:42
verses.text: Let the expounders of a cruel re-absorption keep silence.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:43
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:44
verses.text: Would that they too were silent, who, as they cannot prove that the Word of God and Wisdom of God can be re-absorbed, attribute the weakness of subjection to His Godhead, saying that it is written: "But when all things shall be subdued unto Him, then shall the Son also Himself be subject unto Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:45
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:46
verses.text: We see, then, that the Scripture states that He is not yet made subject, but that this is to come: Therefore now the Son is not made subject to God the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:47
verses.text: In what, then, do ye say that the Son will be made subject? If in His Godhead, He is not disobedient, for He is not at variance with the Father; nor is He made subject, for He is not a servant, but the only Son of His own proper Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:48
verses.text: Lastly, when He created heaven, and formed the earth, He exercised both power and love.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:49
verses.text: There is therefore no subjection as that of a servant in the Godhead of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:50
verses.text: But if there is no subjection then the will is free.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:51
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:52
verses.text: But if they think of this as the subjection of the Son, namely, that the Father makes all things in union with His will, let them learn that this is really a proof of inseparable power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:53
verses.text: For the unity of Their will is one that began not in time, but ever existed.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:54
verses.text: But where there is a constant unity of will, there can be no weakness of temporal subjection.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:55
verses.text: For if He were made subject through His nature, He would always remain in subjection; but since He is said to be made subject in time, that subjection must be part of an assumed office and not of an everlasting weakness: especially as the eternal Power of God cannot change His state for a time, neither can the right of ruling fall to the Father in time.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:56
verses.text: For if the Son ever will be changed in such wise as to be made subject in His Godhead, then also must God the Father, if ever He shall gain more power, and have the Son in subjection to Himself in His Godhead, be considered now in the meantime inferior according to your explanation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:57
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:58
verses.text: But what fault has the Son been guilty of, that we should believe that He could hereafter be made subject in His Godhead? Has he as man seized for Himself the right to sit at His Father's side, or has He claimed for Himself the prerogative of His Father's throne, against His Father's will? But He Himself says: "For I do always those things that please Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:59
verses.text: Therefore if the Son pleases the Father in all things, why should He be made subject, Who was not made subject before?  166.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:60
verses.text: Let us see then that there be not a subjection of the Godhead, but rather of us in the fear of Christ, a truth so full of grace, and so full of mystery.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:61
verses.text: Wherefore, again, let us weigh the Apostle's words: "But when all things shall be subdued unto Him, then shall the Son also Himself be subject unto Him that put all things under Him: that God may be all in all".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:62
verses.text: What then dost thou say? Are not all things now subject unto Him? Are not the choirs of the saints made subject? Are not the angels, who ministered to Him when on the earth? Are not the archangels who were sent to Mary to foretell the coming of the Lord? Are not all the heavenly hosts? Are not the cherubim and seraphim, are not thrones and dominions and powers which worship and praise Him?  167.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:63
verses.text: How, then, will they be brought into subjection? In the way that the Lord Himself has said.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:64
verses.text: "Take My yoke upon you".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:65
verses.text: It is not the fierce that bear the yoke, but the humble and the gentle.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:66
verses.text: This clearly is no base subjection for men, but a glorious one: "that in the Name of Jesus every knee should bow, of things in heaven and things beneath; and that every tongue  should confess that Jesus is Lord in the glory of God the Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:67
verses.text: But for this reason all things were not made subject before, for they had not yet received the wisdom of God, not yet did they wear the easy yoke of the Word on the neck as it were of their mind.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:68
verses.text: "But as many as received Him," as it is written, "to them gave He power to become the sons of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:69
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:70
verses.text: Will any one say that Christ is now made subject, because many have believed? Certainly not.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:71
verses.text: For Christ's subjection lies not in a few but in all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:72
verses.text: For just as I do not seem to be brought into subjection, if the flesh in me as yet lusts against the spirit, and the spirit against the flesh, although I am in part subdued; so because the whole Church is the one body of Christ, we divide Christ as long as the human race disagrees.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:73
verses.text: Therefore Christ is not yet made subject, for His members are not yet brought into subjection.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:74
verses.text: But when we have become, not many members, but one spirit, then He also will become subject, in order that through His subjection "God may be all and in all".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:75
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:76
verses.text: But as Christ is not yet made subject, so is the work of God not yet perfected; for the Son of God said: "My meat is to do the will of My Father that sent Me, and to finish His work".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:77
verses.text: What manner of doubt is there that the subjection of the Son in me is still in the future, in whom the work of the Father is unfinished, because I myself am not yet perfect? I, who make the work of God to be unfinished, do I make the Son of God to be in subjection? But that is not a matter of wrong, it is a matter of grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:78
verses.text: For in so far as we are made subject, it is to our profit, not to that of the Godhead, that we are made subject to the law, that we are made subject to grace.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 13:79
verses.text: For formerly, as the Apostle himself has said, the wisdom of the flesh was at enmity with God, for "it was not made subject to the law," but now it is made subject through the Passion of Christ.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:1
verses.text: Chapter XIV.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:2
verses.text: He continues the discussion of the difficulty he has entered upon, and teaches that Christ is not subject but only according to the flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:3
verses.text: Christ, however, whilst in subjection in the Flesh, still gave proofs of His Godhead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:4
verses.text: He combats the idea that Christ is made subject in This.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:5
verses.text: The humanity indeed, which He adopted, has been so far made subject in us, as ours has been raised in that very humanity of His.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:6
verses.text: Lastly, we are taught, when that same subjection of Christ will take place.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:7
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:8
verses.text: However, lest anyone should cavil, see what care Scripture takes under divine inspiration.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:9
verses.text: For it shows to us in what Christ is made subject to God, whilst it also teaches us in what He made the universe subject to Himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:10
verses.text: And so it says: "Now we see not yet all things put under Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:11
verses.text: For we see Jesus made a little lower than the angels for the suffering of death.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:12
verses.text: It shows therefore that He was made lower in taking on Him our flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:13
verses.text: What then hinders Him from openly showing His subjection in taking on Him our flesh, through which He subjects all things to Himself, whilst He Himself is made subject in it to God the Father?  171.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:14
verses.text: Let us then think of His subjection.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:15
verses.text: "Father," He says, "if Thou be willing, remove this cup from Me; nevertheless not My will but Thine be done".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:16
verses.text: Therefore that subjection will be according to the assumption of human nature; as we read: "Being found in fashion as a man, He humbled Himself, being made obedient unto death".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:17
verses.text: The subjection therefore is that of obedience; the obedience is that of death; the death is that of the assumed humanity; that subjection therefore will be the subjection of the assumed humanity.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:18
verses.text: Thus in no wise is there a weakness in the Godhead, but there is such a discharge of pious duty as this.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:19
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:20
verses.text: See how I do not fear their intentions.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:21
verses.text: They allege that He must be subject to God the Father, I say He was subject to Mary His Mother.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:22
verses.text: For it is written of Joseph and Mary: "He was subject unto them".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:23
verses.text: But if they think so, let them say how the Deity was made subject to men.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:24
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:25
verses.text: Let not the fact that He is said to have been made subject work against Him, Who receives no hurt from the fact that He is called a servant, or is stated to have been crucified, or is spoken of as dead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:26
verses.text: For when He died He lived; when He was made subject He was reigning; when He was buried He revived again.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:27
verses.text: He offered Himself in subjection to human power, yet at another time He declared He was the Lord of eternal glory.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:28
verses.text: He was before the judge, yet claimed for Himself a throne at the right hand of God, as Judge forever.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:29
verses.text: For thus it is written: "Hereafter ye shall see the Son of Man sitting on the right hand of the power of God, and coming in the  clouds of heaven".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:30
verses.text: He was scourged by the Jews, and commanded the angels; He was born of Mary under the law; He was before Abraham above the law.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:31
