verses.text: On the cross He was revered by nature; the sun fled; the earth trembled; the angels became silent.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:32
verses.text: Could the elements see the Generation of Him Whose Passion they feared to see? And will they uphold the subjection of an adorable Nature in Him, in Whom they could not endure the subjection of the body?  174.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:33
verses.text: But since the Father, the Son, and the Holy Spirit are of one Nature, the Father certainly will not be in subjection to Himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:34
verses.text: And therefore the Son will not be in subjection in that in which He is one with the Father; lest it should seem that through the unity of the Godhead the Father also is in subjection to the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:35
verses.text: Therefore, as upon that cross it was not the fulness of the Godhead, but our weakness that was brought into subjection, so also will the Son hereafter become subject to the Father in the participation of our nature, in order that when the lusts of the flesh are brought into subjection the heart may have no care for riches, or ambition, or pleasures; but that God may be all to us, if we live after His image and likeness, as far as we can attain to it, through all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:36
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:37
verses.text: The benefit has passed, then, from the individual to the community; for in His flesh He has tamed the nature of all human flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:38
verses.text: Thus, according to the Apostle: "As we have borne the image of the earthly, so also shall we bear the image of the heavenly".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:39
verses.text: This thing certainly cannot come to pass except in the inner man.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:40
verses.text: Therefore, "laying aside all these," that is those things which we read of: "anger, malice, blasphemy, filthy communication;" as he also says below: "Let us, having put off the old man with his deeds, put on the new man, which is renewed in knowledge after the image of Him that created Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:41
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:42
verses.text: And that thou mightest know that when he says: "That God may be all in all," he does not separate Christ from God the Father, he also says to the Colossians: "Where there is neither male nor female, Jew nor Greek, Barbarian nor Scythian, bond nor free, but Christ is all and in all".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:43
verses.text: So also saying to the Corinthians: "That God may be all and in all," he comprehended in that the unity and equality of Christ with God the Father, for the Son is not separated from the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:44
verses.text: And in like manner as the Father worketh all and in all, so also Christ worketh all in all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:45
verses.text: If, then, Christ also worketh all in all, He is not made subject in the glory of the Godhead, but in us.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:46
verses.text: But how is He made subject in us, except in the way in which He was made lower than the angels, I mean in the sacrament of His body? For all things which served their Creator from their first beginning seemed not as yet to be made subject to Him in that.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:47
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:48
verses.text: But if thou shouldst ask how He was made subject in us, He Himself shows us, saying: "I was in prison, and ye came unto Me; I was sick, and ye visited Me: Inasmuch as ye have done it unto one of the least of these ye have done it unto Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:49
verses.text: Thou hearest of Him as sick and weak, and art not moved.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:50
verses.text: Thou hearest of Him in subjection, and art moved, though He is sick and weak in Him in whom He is in subjection, in whom He was made sin and a curse for us.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:51
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:52
verses.text: As, then, He was made sin and a curse not on His own account but on ours, so He became subject in us not for His own sake but for ours, being not in subjection in His eternal Nature, nor accursed in His eternal Nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:53
verses.text: "For cursed is every one that hangeth on a tree".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:54
verses.text: Cursed He was, for He bore our curses; in subjection, also, for He took upon Him our subjection, but in the assumption of the form of a servant, not in the glory of God; so that whilst he makes Himself a partaker of our weakness in the flesh, He makes us partakers of the divine Nature in His power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:55
verses.text: But neither in one nor the other have we any natural fellowship with the heavenly Generation of Christ, nor is there any subjection of the Godhead in Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:56
verses.text: But as the Apostle has said that on Him through that flesh which is the pledge of our salvation, we sit in heavenly places, though certainly not sitting ourselves, so also He is said to be subject in us through the assumption of our nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:57
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:58
verses.text: For who is so mad as to think, as we have said already, that a seat of honour is due to Him at the right hand of God the Father, when that is granted to Christ according to the flesh by the Father of His Generation, even a seat of a heavenly and equal power? The angels worship, and dost thou attempt to overthrow the throne of God with impious presumption?  180.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:59
verses.text: It is written, thou sayest, that "when we were dead in sins, He hath quickened us  in Christ, by Whose grace ye are saved, and hath raised us up together, and made us sit together in heavenly places in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:60
verses.text: I acknowledge that it is so written; but it is not written that God suffers men to sit on His right hand, but only to sit there in the Person of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:61
verses.text: For He is the foundation of all, and is the head of the Church, in Whom our common nature according to the flesh has merited the right to the heavenly throne.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:62
verses.text: For the flesh is honoured as having a share in Christ Who is God, and the nature of the whole human race is honoured as having a share in the flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:63
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:64
verses.text: As we then sit in Him by fellowship in our fleshly nature, so also He, Who through the assumption of our flesh was made a curse for us (seeing that a curse could not fall upon the blessed Son of God), so, I say, He through the obedience of all will become subject in us; when the Gentile has believed, and the Jew has acknowledged Him Whom he crucified; when the Manichaean has worshipped Him, Whom he has not believed to have come in the flesh; when the Arian has confessed Him to be Almighty, Whom he has denied; when, lastly, the wisdom of God, His justice, peace, love, resurrection, is in all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:65
verses.text: Through His own works and through the manifold forms of virtues Christ will be in us in subjection to the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 14:66
verses.text: And when, with vice renounced and crime at an end, one spirit in the heart of all peoples has begun to cleave to God in all things, then will God be all and in all.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:1
verses.text: Chapter XV.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:2
verses.text: He briefly takes up again the same points of dispute, and shrewdly concludes from the unity of the divine power in the Father and the Son, that whatever is said of the subjection of the Son is to be referred to His humanity alone.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:3
verses.text: He further confirms this on proof of the love, which exists alike in either.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:4
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:5
verses.text: Let us then shortly sum up our conclusion on the whole matter.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:6
verses.text: A unity of power puts aside all idea of a degrading subjection.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:7
verses.text: His giving up of power, and His victory as conqueror won over death, have not lessened His power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:8
verses.text: Obedience works out subjection.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:9
verses.text: Christ has taken obedience upon Himself, obedience even to taking on Him our flesh, the cross even to gaining our salvation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:10
verses.text: Thus where the work lies, there too is the Author of the work.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:11
verses.text: When therefore, all things have become subject to Christ, through Christ's obedience, so that all bend their knees in His name, then He Himself will be all in all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:12
verses.text: For now, since all do not believe, all do not seem to be in subjection.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:13
verses.text: But when all have believed and done the will of God, then Christ will be all and in all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:14
verses.text: And when Christ is all and in all, then will God be all and in all; for the Father abides ever in the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:15
verses.text: How, then, is He shown to be weak, Who redeemed the weak?  183.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:16
verses.text: And lest thou shouldst by chance attribute to the weakness of the Son, that it is written, that God hath put all things in subjection under Him; learn that He has Himself brought all things into subjection to Himself, for it is written: "Our conversation is in heaven, from whence also we look for the Saviour, the Lord Jesus, Who shall change our vile body that it may be fashioned like unto His glorious body according to the working, whereby He is able to subdue all things unto Himself".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:17
verses.text: Thou has learnt, therefore, that He can subdue all things unto Himself according to the working of His Godhead.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:18
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:19
verses.text: Learn now how He receives all things in subjection according to the flesh, as it is written: "Who wrought in Christ, raising Him from the dead, and setting Him at His own right hand in the heavenly places, above principality and power and might and dominion and every name that is named not only in this world, but also in that which is to come; and hath put all things under His feet".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:20
verses.text: According to the flesh then all things are given to Him in subjection; according to which also He was raised from the dead, both in His human soul and His rational subjection.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:21
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:22
verses.text: Many nobly interpret that which is written: "Truly my soul will be in subjection to God;" He said soul not Godhead, soul not glory.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:23
verses.text: And that we might know that the Lord has spoken through the prophet of the adoption of our human nature, He added: "How long will ye cast yourselves upon a man?" As also He says in the Gospel: "Why do ye seek to kill Me, a man?" And He added again: "Nevertheless they desired to refuse My price, they ran in thirst, they blessed with their mouth, and cursed with their heart".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:24
verses.text: For the Jews, when Judas brought back the price, would not receive it, running on in the thirst of madness, for they refused the grace of a spiritual draught.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:25
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:26
verses.text: This is the reverent interpretation of subjection, for since this is the office of the  Lord's Passion, He will be subject in us in that in which He suffered.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:27
verses.text: Do we ask wherefore? That "neither angels, nor powers, nor height, nor depth, nor things present, nor things to come, nor any other creature may separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:28
verses.text: We see then, from what has been said, that no creature is excepted; but that every one, of whatever kind it may be, is enumerated among those he mentioned above.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:29
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:30
verses.text: At the same time, we must also think of the words which, after first saying "Who shall separate us from the love of Christ?" he wrote next: "Neither death, nor life, nor any other creature can separate us from the love of God, which is in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:31
verses.text: We see, then, that the love of God is the same as the love of Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:32
verses.text: Thus it was not without reason that he wrote of the love of God, "which is in Christ Jesus," lest otherwise thou mightest imagine that the love of God and of Christ was divided.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 15:33
verses.text: But there is nothing that love divides, nothing that the eternal Godhead cannot do, nothing that is unknown to the Truth, or deceives Justice, or escapes the notice of Wisdom.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:1
verses.text: Chapter XVI.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:2
verses.text: The Arians are condemned by the Holy Spirit through the mouth of David: for they dare to limit Christ's knowledge.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:3
verses.text: The passage cited by them in proof of this is by no means free from suspicion of having been corrupted.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:4
verses.text: But to set this right, we must mark the word "Son".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:5
verses.text: For knowledge cannot fail Christ as Son of God, since He is Wisdom; nor the recognition of any part, for He created all things.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:6
verses.text: It is not possible that He, who made the ages, cannot know the future, much less the day of judgment.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:7
verses.text: Such knowledge, whether it concerns anything great or small, may not be denied to the Son, nor yet to the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:8
verses.text: Lastly, various proofs are given from which we can gather that this knowledge exists in Christ.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:9
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:10
verses.text: Wherefore we ought to know that they who make such statements are accursed and condemned by the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:11
verses.text: For whom else but the Arians in chief does the prophet condemn, seeing that they say that the Son of God knows neither times nor years.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:12
verses.text: For there is nothing which God is ignorant of; and Christ, yea the most high Christ, is God, for He is "God over all".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:13
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:14
verses.text: See how horrified holy David is at such men, in limiting the knowledge of the Son of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:15
verses.text: For thus it is written: "They are not in the troubles of other men, neither will they be scourged with men; therefore their pride has laid hold on them; they are covered with their wickedness and blasphemy; their iniquity hath stood forth as it were with fatness; they have passed on to the thoughts of their heart".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:16
verses.text: Truly he condemns those who think that divine things are to be regarded in the light of the thoughts of the heart.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:17
verses.text: For God is not subject to arrangement or order; seeing that we do not perceive even those very things, which are common among men and often occur in the history of the human race, to turn out always after the arrangement of some stated rule, but often to happen suddenly in some secret and mysterious manner.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:18
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:19
verses.text: "They have thought," he says, "and have spoken wickedness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:20
verses.text: They have spoken wickedness against the Most High.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:21
verses.text: They have set their mouth against heaven".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:22
verses.text: We see then that he condemns, as guilty of wicked blasphemy, those who claim for themselves the right to arrange the heavenly secrets after the semblance of our human nature.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:23
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:24
verses.text: And they have said: "How hath God known? And is there knowledge in the Most High?" Do not the Arians echo this daily, saying that all knowledge cannot exist in Christ? For He, they say, stated that He knew not the day nor hour.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:25
verses.text: Do they not say, how did He know, while they maintain that He could not know anything but what He heard and saw, and apply by a blasphemous interpretation that which concerns the unity of the divine Nature to weaken His power?  192.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:26
verses.text: It is written, they say: "But of that day and that hour knoweth no man, no, not the angels which are in heaven, neither the Son, but the Father only".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:27
verses.text: First of all the ancient Greek manuscripts do not contain the words, "neither the Son".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:28
verses.text: But it is not to be wondered at if they who have corrupted the sacred Scriptures, have also falsified this passage.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:29
verses.text: The reason for which it seems to have been inserted is perfectly plain, so long as it is applied to unfold such blasphemy.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:30
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:31
verses.text: Suppose however that the Evangelist wrote thus.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:32
verses.text: The name of "Son" embraces both natures.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:33
verses.text: For He is also called Son of Man, so that in the ignorance attached to the assumption of our nature, He seems not to have known the day of the judgment to come.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:34
verses.text: For how could the Son  of God be ignorant of the day, seeing that the treasures of the wisdom and knowledge of God are hidden in Him?  194.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:35
verses.text: I ask then, whether He had this knowledge by reason of His Being, or by chance? For all knowledge comes to us either through nature, or by learning.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:36
verses.text: It is supplied by nature, as for instance to a horse to enable it to run, or to a fish to enable it to swim.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:37
verses.text: For they do this without learning.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:38
verses.text: On the other hand, it is by learning that a man is enabled to swim.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:39
verses.text: For he could not do so unless he had learnt.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:40
verses.text: Since therefore nature enables dumb animals to do and to know what they have not learnt, why shouldst thou give an opinion on the Son of God, and say whether He has knowledge by instruction or by nature? If by instruction, then He was not begotten as Wisdom, and gradually began to be perfect, but was not always so.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:41
verses.text: But if He has knowledge by nature, then He was perfect in the beginning, He came forth perfect from the Father; and so needed no foreknowledge of the future.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:42
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:43
verses.text: He therefore was not ignorant of the days; for it does not fall to the lot of the Wisdom of God to know in part and in part to be ignorant.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:44
verses.text: For how can He who made all things be ignorant of a part, since it is a less thing to know than to make.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:45
verses.text: For we know many things which we cannot make, neither do we all know things in the same way but we know them in part.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:46
verses.text: For a countryman knows the force of the wind and the courses of the stars in one way—the inhabitant of a city knows them in another way—and a pilot in yet a third way.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:47
verses.text: But although all do not know all things, they are said to know them; but He alone knows all things in full, Who made all things.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:48
verses.text: The pilot knows for how many watches Arcturus continues, what sort of a rising of Orion he will discover, but he knows nothing of the connection of the Vergiliae and of the other stars, or of their number or names, as does He "Who numbers the multitude of stars, and calleth them all by their names;" Whom indeed the power of His work cannot escape.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:49
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:50
verses.text: How then do you wish the Son of God to have made these things? Like a signet ring which does not feel the impression it makes? But the Father made all things in wisdom, that is, He made all things through the Son, who is the Virtue and Wisdom of God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:51
verses.text: But it befits such Wisdom as that to know both the powers and the causes of His own works.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:52
verses.text: Thus the Creator of all things could not be ignorant of what He did—or be without knowledge of what He had Himself given.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:53
verses.text: Therefore He knew the day which He made.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:54
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:55
verses.text: But thou sayest that He knows the present and does not know the future.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:56
verses.text: Though this is a foolish suggestion, yet that I may satisfy thee on Scriptural grounds, learn that He made not only what is past, but also what is future, as it is written: "Who made things to come".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:57
verses.text: Elsewhere too Scripture says: "By whom also He made the ages, who is the brightness of His glory and the express Image of His Person".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:58
verses.text: Now the ages are past and present and future.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:59
verses.text: How then were those made which are future, unless it is that His active power and knowledge contains within itself the number of all the ages? For just as He calls the things that are not as though they were, so has He made things future as though they were.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:60
verses.text: It cannot come to pass that they should not be.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:61
verses.text: Those things which He has directed to be, necessarily will be.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:62
verses.text: Therefore He who has made the things that are to be, knows them in the way in which they will be.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:63
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:64
verses.text: If we are to believe this about the ages, much more must we believe it about the day of judgment, on the ground that the Son of God has knowledge of it, as being already made by Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:65
verses.text: For it is written: "According to Thine ordinance the day will continue".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:66
verses.text: He did not merely say "the day continues," but even "will continue," so that the things which are to come might be governed by His ordinance.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:67
verses.text: Does He not know what He ordered? "He who planted the ear, shall He not hear? He that formed the eye shall He not see?"  199.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:68
verses.text: Let us however see if by chance there may be some great thing, which could be beyond the knowledge of its Creator; or at least let them choose whether they will think of something great and superior to other things, or something very little and mean.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:69
verses.text: If it is very little and mean, it is no loss, to speak after our fashion, to know nothing of worthless and petty things.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:70
verses.text: For as it is a sign of power to know the greatest things, it seems rather to be a sign of inferior work to look upon what is worth less.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:71
verses.text: Thus He is freed from fastidiousness, yet is not deprived of His power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:72
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:73
verses.text: But if they think it a great and important thing to know the day of judgment: Let them say what is greater or better than God the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:74
verses.text: He knows God the Father, as He Himself says: "No man knoweth the Father but the Son and he to whomsoever the Son will reveal Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:75
verses.text: I say, does He know the Father and yet not know the day? So then ye believe that He reveals the Father, and yet cannot reveal the day?  201.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:76
verses.text: Next because you make certain grades, so as to put the Father before the Son, and the Son before the Holy Spirit, tell me whether the Holy Spirit knew the day of judgment.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:77
verses.text: For no thing is written of Him in this place.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:78
verses.text: You deny it entirely.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:79
verses.text: But what if I show you He knew it? For it is written: "But God hath revealed them to us by His Spirit, for the Spirit searcheth all things, yea the deep things of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:80
verses.text: Wherefore, because He searches the deep things of God, since God knows the day of judgment, the Spirit also knows it.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:81
verses.text: For He knows all that God knows, as also the Apostle states, saying: "For what man knoweth the things of a man, save the spirit of man which is in him, even so the things of God knoweth no man, but the Spirit of God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:82
verses.text: Take heed therefore lest either by denying that the Holy Spirit knows, you should deny that the Father knows; (For the things of God, the Spirit of God also knows, but the things which the Spirit of God does not know, are not the things of God).

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:83
verses.text: Or by confessing that the Spirit of God knows, what you deny that the Son of God knows, you should put the Spirit before the Son in opposition to your own declaration.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:84
verses.text: But to hesitate on this point is not only blasphemous but also foolish.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:85
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:86
verses.text: Now consider how knowledge is acquired, and let us show that the Son Himself proved that He knew the day.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:87
verses.text: For what we know we make clear either by mention of time or place or signs or persons, or by giving their order.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:88
verses.text: How then did He not know the day of judgment Who described both the hour and the place of judgment, and the signs and the cases?  203.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:89
verses.text: And so thou hast it: "In that hour he which shall be on the housetop let him not come down to take his goods out of his house, and he that is in the field, let him likewise not return back".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:90
verses.text: To such a point in the future did He know the issues of dangers, that He even showed the means of safety to those in danger.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:91
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:92
verses.text: Could the Lord be ignorant of a day Who Himself said of Himself that the Son of Man is Lord of the Sabbath?  205.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:93
verses.text: He has also elsewhere marked out a place, when He said to His disciples who were showing Him the building of the temple, "Do ye see all these things? Verily I say unto you, there shall not be left one stone upon another which shall not be thrown down".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:94
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:95
verses.text: When questioned also about a sign by His disciples, He answered: "Take heed that ye be not deceived.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:96
verses.text: For many shall come in My name, saying I am Christ;" and further on He says: "and great earthquakes shall be in divers places, and famines, and pestilences, and terrors from heaven, and there shall be great signs".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:97
verses.text: Thus He has described both persons and signs.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:98
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:99
verses.text: In what manner He tells that the armies will surround Jerusalem, or that the times of the Gentiles are to be fulfilled, and in what order,—all this is disclosed to us by the witness of the Gospel words.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 16:100
verses.text: Therefore He knew all things.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:1
verses.text: Chapter XVII.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:2
verses.text: Christ acted for our advantage in being unwilling to reveal the day of judgment.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:3
verses.text: This is made plain by other words of our Lord and by a not dissimilar passage from Paul's writings.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:4
verses.text: Other passages in which the same ignorance seems to be attributed to the Father are brought forward to meet those who are anxious to know why Christ answered His disciples, as though He did not know.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:5
verses.text: From these Ambrose argues against them that if they admit ignorance and inability in the Father, they must admit that the same Substance exists in the Son as in the Father; unless they prefer to accuse the Son of falsehood; since it belongs neither to Him nor to the Father to deceive, but the unity of both is pointed out in the passage named.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:6
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:7
verses.text: But we ask for what reason He was unwilling to state the time.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:8
verses.text: If we ask it, we shall not find it is owing to ignorance, but to wisdom.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:9
verses.text: For it was not to our advantage to know; in order that we being ignorant of the actual moments of judgment to come, might ever be as it were on guard, and set on the watch-tower of virtue, and so avoid the habits of sin; lest the day of the Lord should come upon us in the midst of our wickedness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:10
verses.text: For it is not to our advantage to know but rather to fear the future; for it is written: "Be not high-minded but fear".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:11
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:12
verses.text: For if He had distinctly stated the day, he would seem to have laid down a rule  of life for that one age which was nearest to the judgment, and the just man in the earlier times would be more negligent, and the sinner more free from care.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:13
verses.text: For the adulterer cannot cease from the desire of committing adultery unless he fears punishment day by day, nor can the robber forsake the hiding places in the woods where he dwells, unless he knows punishment is hanging over him day by day.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:14
verses.text: For impurity generally spurs them on, but fear is irksome to the end.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:15
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:16
verses.text: Therefore I have said that it was not to our advantage to know; nay, it is to our advantage to be ignorant, that through ignorance we might fear, through watchfulness be corrected, as He Himself said: "Be ye ready, for ye know not at what hour the Son of Man cometh".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:17
verses.text: For the soldier does not know how to watch in the camp unless he knows that war is at hand.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:18
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:19
verses.text: Wherefore at another time also the Lord Himself when asked by his Apostles (Yes, for they did not understand it as Arius did, but believed that the Son of God knew the future.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:20
verses.text: For unless they had believed this, they would never have asked the question.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:21
verses.text: )—the Lord, I say, when asked when He would restore the kingdom to Israel, did not say that He did not know, but says: "It is not for you to know the times or years, which the Father hath put in His own power".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:22
verses.text: Mark what He said: It is not for you to know! Read again, "It is not for you".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:23
verses.text: "For you," He said, not "for Me," for now He spoke not according to His own perfection but as was profitable to the human body and our soul.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:24
verses.text: "For you" therefore He said, not "for Me".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:25
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:26
verses.text: Which example the Apostle also followed: "But of the times and seasons, brethren," he says, "ye have no need that I write unto you".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:27
verses.text: Thus not even the Apostle himself, the servant of Christ, said that he knew not the seasons, but that there was no need for the people to be taught; for they ought ever to be armed with spiritual armour, that the virtue of Christ may stand forth in each one.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:28
verses.text: But when the Lord says: "Of the times which the Father hath put in His own power," He certainly cannot be without a share in His Father's knowledge, in whose power He is by no means without a share.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:29
verses.text: For power grows out of wisdom and virtue; and Christ is both of these.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:30
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:31
verses.text: But you ask, why did He not refuse His disciples as one who knew, but would not say; and, why did He state instead that neither the angels nor the Son knew? I too will ask you why God says in Genesis: "I will go down now, and see whether they have done altogether according to the cry that is come unto Me.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:32
verses.text: And if not, that I may know".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:33
verses.text: Why does Scripture also say of God: "And the Lord came down to see the city and the tower, which the sons of men builded".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:34
verses.text: Why also does the prophet say in the Book of the Psalms: "The Lord looked down upon the children of men, to see if there were any that did understand, and that did seek God"? Just as though in one place, if God had not descended, and in the other, if He had not looked down, He would have been ignorant either of men's work or of their merits.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:35
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:36
verses.text: But in the Gospel of Luke also thou hast the same, for the Father says: "What shall I do? I will send My beloved Son; it may be that they will reverence Him".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:37
verses.text: In Matthew and in Mark thou hast: "But He sent His only Son, saying: they will reverence My Son;" In one book He says: "It may be that they will reverence My Son;" and is in doubt as though He does not know; for this is the language of one in doubt.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:38
verses.text: But in the two other books He says: "They will reverence My Son;" that is, He declares that reverence will be shown.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:39
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:40
verses.text: But God can neither be in doubt, nor can He be deceived.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:41
verses.text: For he only is in doubt, who is ignorant of the future; and he is deceived, who has predicted one thing, whilst another has happened.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:42
verses.text: Yet what is plainer than the fact that Scripture states the Father to have said one thing of the Son, and that the same Scripture proves another think to have taken place? The Son was beaten, He was mocked, was crucified, and died.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:43
verses.text: He suffered much worse things in the flesh than those servants who had been appointed before.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:44
verses.text: Was the Father deceived, or was He ignorant of it, or was He unable to give help? But He that is true cannot make a mistake; for it is written: "God is faithful Who doth not lie".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:45
verses.text: How was He ignorant, Who knows all? What could He not do, Who could do all?  216.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:46
verses.text: Yet if either He was ignorant, or had not power (for you would sooner agree to say that the Father did not know than own that the Son knows), you see from this very  fact that the Son is of one Substance with the Father; seeing that the Son like the Father (to speak in accordance with your foolish ideas) does not know all things, and cannot do all things.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:47
verses.text: For I am not so eager or rash in giving praise to the Son as to dare to say that the Son can do more than the Father; for I make no distinction of power between the Father and the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:48
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:49
verses.text: But perhaps you say that the Father did not say so, but that the Son erred about the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:50
verses.text: So now you convict the Son not only of weakness, but also of blasphemy and lying.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:51
verses.text: However if you do not believe the Son with regard to the Father, neither may you believe Him with regard to that.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:52
verses.text: For if He wished to deceive us in saying that the Father was in doubt as though He knew not what would take place, He wished also to deceive us about Himself in saying that He did not know the future.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:53
verses.text: It would be far more endurable for Him to stretch the veil of ignorance in front of that which He does of His own accord, than that He should seem to be deluded by a result contrary to what He had foretold in the things He had declared of His Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:54
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:55
verses.text: But neither is the Father deceived, not does the Son deceive.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:56
verses.text: It is the custom of the holy Scriptures to speak thus, as the examples I have already given, and many others testify, so that God feigns not to know what He does know.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 17:57
verses.text: In this then a unity of Godhead, and a unity of character is proved to exist in the Father and in the Son; seeing that, as God the Father hides what is known to Him, so also the Son, Who is the image of God in this respect, hides what is known to Him.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:1
verses.text: Chapter XVIII.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:2
verses.text: Wishing to give a reason for the Lord's answer to the apostles, he assigns the one received to Christ's tenderness.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:3
verses.text: Then when another reason is supplied by others he confesses that it is true; for the Lord spoke it by reason of His human feelings.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:4
verses.text: Hence he gathers that the knowledge of the Father and the Son is equal, and that the Son is not inferior to the Father.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:5
verses.text: After having set beside the text, in which He is said to be inferior, another whereby He is declared to be equal, he censures the rashness of the Arians in judging about the Son, and shows that whilst they wickedly make Him to be inferior, He is rightly called a Stone by Himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:6
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:7
verses.text: We have been taught therefore that the Son of God is not ignorant of the future.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:8
verses.text: If they confess this, I too—that I may now answer why He declared that neither angels, nor the Son, but only the Father knows—call to mind His wonted love for His disciples also in this passage, and His grace, which by its very frequency ought to have been known to all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:9
verses.text: For the Lord, filled with deep love for His disciples, when they asked from Him what He thought unprofitable for them to know, prefers to seem ignorant of what He knows, rather than to refuse an answer.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:10
verses.text: He loves rather to provide what is useful for us, than to show His own power.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:11
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:12
verses.text: There are, however, some not so faint-hearted as I.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:13
verses.text: For I would rather fear the deep things of God, than be wise.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:14
verses.text: There are some, however, relying on the words: "And Jesus increased in age and in wisdom and in favour with God and man," who boldly say, that according to His Godhead indeed He could not be ignorant of the future, but that in His assumption of our human state He said that He as Son of Man was in ignorance before His crucifixion.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:15
verses.text: For when He speaks of the Son, He does not speak as it were of another; for He Himself is our Lord the Son of God and the Son of a Virgin.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:16
verses.text: But by a word which embraces both, He guides our mind, so that He as Son of Man according to His adoption of our ignorance and growth of knowledge, might be believed as yet not fully to have known all things.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:17
verses.text: For it is not for us to know the future.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:18
verses.text: Thus He seems to be ignorant in that state in which He makes progress.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:19
verses.text: For how does He progress according to His Godhead, in Whom the fulness of the Godhead dwells? Or what is there which the Son of God does not know, Who said: "Why think ye evil in your hearts?" How does He not know, of Whom Scripture says: "But Jesus knew their thoughts"?  221.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:20
verses.text: This is what others say, but I—to return to my former point, where I stated it was written of the Father: "It may be they will reverence My Son,"—I think indeed this was written in order that the Father, as He was speaking of men, might also seem to have spoken with human feelings.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:21
verses.text: But still more am I inclined to think that the Son Who went about with men, and lived the life of man, and took upon Him our flesh, assumed also our feelings; so that after our ignorance He might say He knew not, though there was not anything He did not know.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:22
verses.text: For though He seemed to be a man in the reality of His body, yet was He Life, and Light, and virtue came out of Him, to heal the  wounds of the injured by the power of His Majesty.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:23
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:24
verses.text: Ye see then that this matter has been solved for you, since the saying of the Son is referred to the assumption of our state in its fulness, and it was thus written concerning the Father, in order that you might cease to cavil at the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:25
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:26
verses.text: There was nothing then of which the Son of God was ignorant, for there was nothing of which the Father was ignorant.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:27
verses.text: But if the Son was ignorant of nothing, as we now conclude, let them say in what respect they wish Him to seem to be inferior.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:28
verses.text: If God has begotten a Son inferior to Himself, He has granted Him less.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:29
verses.text: If He has granted Him less, He either wished to give less, or could only give less.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:30
verses.text: But the Father is neither weak nor envious, seeing that there was neither will nor power before the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:31
verses.text: For wherein is He inferior, Who has all things even as the Father has them? He has received all things from the Father by right of His Generation, and has shown forth the Father wholly by the glory of His Majesty.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:32
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:33
verses.text: It is written, they say: "For the Father is greater than I".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:34
verses.text: It is also written: "He thought it not robbery to be equal with God".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:35
verses.text: It is written again that the Jews wished to kill Him, because He said He was the Son of God, making Himself equal with God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:36
verses.text: It is written: "I and My Father are one".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:37
verses.text: They read "one," they do not read "many".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:38
verses.text: Can He then be both inferior and equal in the same Nature? Nay, the one refers to His Godhead, the other to His flesh.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:39
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:40
verses.text: They say He is inferior: I ask who has measured it, who is of so overweening a heart, as to place the Father and the Son before his judgment seat to decide upon which is the greater? "My heart is not haughty nor are mine eyes raised unto vanity," says David.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:41
verses.text: King David feared to raise his heart in pride in human affairs, but we raise ours even in opposition to the divine secrets.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:42
verses.text: Who shall decide about the Son of God? Thrones, dominions, angels, powers? But archangels give attendance and serve Him, cherubim and seraphim minister to Him and praise Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:43
verses.text: Who then decides about the Son of God, on reading that the Father Himself knows the Son, but will not judge Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:44
verses.text: "For no man knoweth the Son, but the Father".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:45
verses.text: "Knoweth" it says, not "judgeth".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:46
verses.text: It is one thing to know, another to judge.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:47
verses.text: The Father has knowledge in Himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:48
verses.text: The Son has no power superior to Himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:49
verses.text: And again: "No man knoweth the Father, but the Son;" and He Himself knows the Father, as the Father knows Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:50
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:51
verses.text: But thou sayest that He said He was inferior, He said also He was a Stone.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:52
verses.text: Thou sayest more and yet dost impiously attack Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:53
verses.text: I say less and with reverence add to His honour.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:54
verses.text: Thou sayest He is inferior and confessest Him to be above the angels.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 18:55
verses.text: I say He is less than the angels, yet do not take from His honour; for I do not refute His Godhead, but I do proclaim His pity.

chapters.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:1
verses.text: Chapter XIX.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:2
verses.text: The Saint having turned to God the Father, explains why he does not deride that the Son is inferior to the Father, then he declares it is not for him to measure the Son of God, since it was given to an angel—nay, perhaps even to Christ as man—to measure merely Jerusalem.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:3
verses.text: Arius, he says, has shown himself to be an imitator of Satan.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:4
verses.text: It is a rash thing to hold discussions on the divine Generation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:5
verses.text: Since so great a sign of human generation has been given by Isaiah, we ought not to make comparisons in divine things.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:6
verses.text: Lastly he shows how carefully we ought to avoid the pride of Arius, by putting before us various examples of Scriptures.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:7
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:8
verses.text: To Thee now, Almighty Father, do I direct my words with tears.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:9
verses.text: I indeed have readily called Thee inapproachable, incomprehensible, inestimable; but I dared not say Thy Son was inferior to Thyself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:10
verses.text: For when I read that He is the Brightness of Thy glory, and the Image of Thy Person, I fear lest, in saying that the Image of Thy Person is inferior, I should seem to say that Thy Person is inferior, of which the Son is the Image; for the fulness of Thy Godhead is wholly in the Son.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:11
verses.text: I have often read, I freely believe, that Thou and Thy Son and the Holy Spirit are boundless, unmeasurable, inestimable, ineffable.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:12
verses.text: And therefore I cannot appraise Thee so as to weigh Thee.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:13
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:14
verses.text: But be it so, that I desired with a daring and rash spirit to measure Thee? From whence, I ask, shall I measure Thee? The prophet saw a line of flax with which the angel measured Jerusalem.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:15
verses.text: An angel was measuring, not Arius.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:16
verses.text: And he was measuring Jerusalem, not God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:17
verses.text: And perchance even an angel could not measure Jerusalem, for it was a man.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:18
verses.text: Thus it is written: "I raised mine eyes and saw and beheld a man, and in his hand there was a  line of flax".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:19
verses.text: He was a man, for a type of the body that was to be assumed was thus shown.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:20
verses.text: He was a man, of whom it was said: "There cometh a man after me, Whose shoe's latchet I am not worthy to unloose".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:21
verses.text: Therefore Christ in a type measures Jerusalem.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:22
verses.text: Arius measures God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:23
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:24
verses.text: Even Satan transforms himself into an angel of light; what wonder then if Arius imitates his Author in taking upon himself what is forbidden? Though his father the devil did it not in his own case, that man with intolerable blasphemy assumes to himself the knowledge of divine secrets and the mysteries of the heavenly Generation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:25
verses.text: For the devil confessed the true Son of God, Arius denies Him.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:26
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:27
verses.text: If, then, I cannot measure Thee, Almighty Father, can I without blasphemy discuss the secrets of Thy Generation? Can I say there is anything more or less between Thee and Thy Son when He Himself Who was begotten of Thee, says: "All things which the Father hath are Mine".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:28
verses.text: Who has made Me a judge and a divider of human affairs? This the Son says, and do we claim to make a division and to give judgment between the Father and the Son? A right feeling of duty avoids arbiters even in the division of an inheritance.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:29
verses.text: And shall we become arbiters, to divide between Thee and Thy Son the glory of the uncreated Substance?  231.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:30
verses.text: "This generation," it says, "is an evil generation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:31
verses.text: It seeketh a sign, and there shall no sign be given it, but the sign of Jonas the prophet".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:32
verses.text: A sign of the Godhead then is not given, but only of the Incarnation.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:33
verses.text: Thus when about to speak of the Incarnation the prophet says: "Ask thee a sign".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:34
verses.text: And when the king had said: "I will not ask, neither will I tempt the Lord," the answer was: "Behold a Virgin shall conceive".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:35
verses.text: Therefore we cannot see a sign of the Godhead, and do we seek a measure of it? Alas! woe is me! we impiously dare to discuss Him, to Whom we cannot worthily pray!  232.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:36
verses.text: Let the Arians see to what they do.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:37
verses.text: I have unlawfully compared Thee, O Father, with Thy works in saying that Thou art greater than all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:38
verses.text: If greater than Thy Son, as Arius maintains, I have judged wickedly.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:39
verses.text: Concerning Thee first will that judgment be.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:40
verses.text: For no choice can be made except by comparison, nor can anyone be put before another without a decision being first given on Himself.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:41
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:42
verses.text: It is not lawful for us to swear by heaven, but it is lawful to judge about God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:43
verses.text: Yet Thou hast given to Thy Son alone judgment over all.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:44
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:45
verses.text: John feared to baptize the flesh of the Lord, John forbade Him, saying: "I have need to be baptized of Thee, and comest Thou to me?" And shall I bring Christ under my judgment?  235.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:46
verses.text: Moses excuses himself from the Priesthood, Peter is for avoiding the obedience demanded in the Ministry; and does Arius examine even the deep things of God? But Arius is not the Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:47
verses.text: Nay, it was said even to Arius and to all men: "Seek not that which is too deep for thee".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:48
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:49
verses.text: Moses is prevented from seeing the face of God; Arius merited to see it in secret.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:50
verses.text: Moses and Aaron among His Priests.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:51
verses.text: Moses who appeared with the Lord in glory, that Moses then saw only the back parts of God in appearance; Arius beholds God wholly face to face! But "no one," it says, "can see My face and live".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:52
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:53
verses.text: Paul also speaks of inferior beings: "We know in part and we prophesy in part".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:54
verses.text: Arius says: "I know God altogether and not in part".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:55
verses.text: Thus Paul is inferior to Arius, and the vessel of election knows in part, but the vessel of perdition knows wholly.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:56
verses.text: "I know," he says, "a man, whether in the body or out of the body, I cannot tell, God knoweth, how he was caught up into Paradise and heard unspeakable words".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:57
verses.text: Paul carried up to the third heaven, knew not himself; Arius rolling in filth, knows God.

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:58
verses.text: Paul says of himself: "God knows;" Arius says of God: "I know".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:59
Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:60
verses.text: But Arius was not caught up to heaven, although he followed him who with accursed boastfulness presumed on what was divine, saying: "I will set my throne upon the clouds; I will be like the Most High".

verses.name: Ambrose: Exposition of the Christian Faith Book V 19:61
verses.text: For as he said: "I will be like the Most High," so too Arius wishes the Most High Son of God to seem like himself, Whom he does not worship in the eternal glory of His Godhead, but measures by the weakness of the flesh.
